title: 2023 South Africa floods
input: The floods in South Africa in February-March 2023 were caused by heavy rainfall as a result of the La Niña weather phenomenon, affecting seven provinces, including Eastern Cape, Northern Cape, Mpumalanga, KwaZulu-Natal, and North West. The floods have caused casualties and damage to homes, businesses, basic infrastructure, roads, bridges and affected crops and livestock. At least twelve people have died across the provinces and others are missing. In addition to that, two more fatalities have been reported in King Sabata Dalindyebo Local Municipality (Eastern Cape Province), and one person in Komani Town (formerly Queenstown). Several people have been evacuated in Lekwa Local Municipality and residents in the area of Vaal, Vanderkloof, and Bloemhof dams along the Orange River (Northern Cape Province) were invited to evacuate after controlled water
paraphrase: Heavy rainfall due to the La Niña weather phenomenon caused floods in South Africa between February and March 2023, affecting seven provinces, including Eastern Cape, Northern Cape, Mpumalanga, KwaZulu-Natal, and North West. The floods resulted in casualties, damage to homes, businesses, basic infrastructure, roads, bridges, and crops and livestock. Across the provinces, at least twelve people have died, and others are missing. Additionally, two fatalities were reported in King Sabata Dalindyebo Local Municipality (Eastern Cape Province), and one person in Komani Town (formerly Queenstown). In Lekwa Local Municipality, several people were evacuated, and residents in the areas of Vaal, Vanderkloof, and Bloemhof dams along the Orange River (Northern Cape Province) were advised to evacuate after controlled water releases.

title: 19th British Academy Games Awards
input: The 19th British Academy Video Game Awards were hosted by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts on 30 March 2023 to honour the best video games of 2022. Held at the Queen Elizabeth Hall in London, the ceremony was hosted by esports presenter Frankie Ward, taking over from Elle Osili-Wood who hosted the previous two ceremonies. The ceremony was livestreamed exclusively on BAFTA's Twitch channel, hosted by games journalist Julia Hardy and comedian Inel Tomlinson. Red carpet coverage was presented by Eurogamer's Aoife Wilson. Sony Interactive's God of War Ragnarök received the most nominations, with fifteen, becoming the most nominated game in the history of the BAFTA Games Awards. While God of War Ragnarök won the most awards at the ceremony, with six, the top honour,

The ceremony was livestreamed exclusively on BAFTA's Twitch channel, with games journalist Julia Hardy and comedian Inel Tomlinson as the hosts. Eurogamer's Aoife Wilson presented the red carpet coverage. God of War Ragnarök from Sony Interactive received the most nominations, with fifteen, making it the most nominated game in the history of the BAFTA Games Awards. Although God of War Ragnarök won the most awards at the ceremony, with six, the top prize was not mentioned.

title: 2014 Fijian general election
input: General elections were held in Fiji on 17 September 2014 to select the 50 members of Parliament. The FijiFirst party led by Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama won a landslide victory, winning 32 of the 50 seats. The Social Democratic Liberal Party and the National Federation Party were the only other two parties to cross the 5% electoral threshold and win seats.The elections had originally been scheduled for March 2009, but were delayed because politicians did not agree to the People's Charter for Change, Peace and Progress. Between 2009 and 2014 several public announcements and requests were made for elections, and on 23 March 2014 the interim government announced the elections would be held on 17 September 2014. The elections were to be held under the new constitution which
paraphrase: In September 2014, Fiji held general elections to choose 50 members of Parliament. The FijiFirst party, led by Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama, won a significant victory, securing 32 of the 50 seats. The Social Democratic Liberal Party and the National Federation Party were the only other parties to win seats by crossing the 5% electoral threshold. Originally scheduled for March 2009, the elections were postponed due to disagreements over the People's Charter for Change, Peace and Progress. Between 2009 and 2014, there were several calls for elections, and on 23 March 2014, the interim government announced that the elections would take place on 17 September 2014. The elections were held under the new constitution.

title: 2023 France–China Summit
input: The 2023 France–China summit was a three-day state visit by Emmanuel Macron, the President of France, to China from April 5 to 7, 2023. It was Macron's first visit to China since the COVID-19 pandemic and his third since taking office in 2017. He was accompanied by a delegation of more than 50 CEOs and met with the French business community in China. He also met with Xi Jinping, the General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party and President of China, and Ursula von der Leyen, the President of the European Commission, to discuss various issues, especially the ongoing war in Ukraine and China's potential role as a mediator between Russia and the West. The visit was seen as an attempt to "reconnect" with China after three years
paraphrase: of absence due to the COVID-19 pandemic and to strengthen economic and political ties between France and China. This was his first visit to China since the pandemic and his third since taking office in 2017. During the visit, he met with the French business community in China, as well as with Xi Jinping, the General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party and President of China, and Ursula von der Leyen, the President of the European Commission. The discussions focused on various issues, including the ongoing war in Ukraine and China's potential role as a mediator between Russia and the West. The visit was seen as an effort to strengthen the relationship between France and China after a three-year absence.

title: 1st Hollywood Critics Association Creative Arts Awards
input: The 1st Hollywood Critics Association Creative Arts Awards, presented by the Hollywood Critics Association, took place on February 24, 2023. The winners were announced on the official HCA Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, while the 6th Hollywood Critics Association Film Awards took place on the same day at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel, Beverly Hills. The nominations were announced on the HCA official YouTube channel and app on December 8, 2022.Everything Everywhere All at Once led the nominations with six, followed by The Batman and Top Gun: Maverick with five each. The former and Babylon won the most awards with two wins each.A shortlist committee, led by Erik Anderson, AwardsWatch contributor and HCA member, was created and tasked with generating twelve category shortlists for the HCA Creative Arts Awards. Six
paraphrase: The Hollywood Critics Association held its first Creative Arts Awards on February 24, 2023, while the sixth Film Awards took place on the same day at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Beverly Hills. The winners of the Creative Arts Awards were announced on the HCA's official social media accounts, while the nominations were revealed on the HCA's YouTube channel and app on December 8, 2022. Everything Everywhere All at Once received the most nominations with six, followed by The Batman and Top Gun: Maverick with five each. Babylon and The former won two awards each. A committee, led by Erik Anderson, AwardsWatch contributor and HCA member, was responsible for creating twelve category shortlists for the Creative Arts Awards. Six categories were awarded.

title: Counterinsurgency in Northern Afghanistan
input: The following addresses the events in Northern Afghanistan between April 2009 and 2014. While this part of the country had long been relatively peaceful compared to the all-out war zones of the south and east, tensions would flare up again in 2008 when the German soldiers deployed to the area came under attack more often, leading to the deaths of the several soldiers. Previously hindered by national caveats, the deteroriating security situation prompted the German-led Regional Command North to launch a series of operations to take on the rising insurgency. Concerted operations began after an insurgent attack on PRT Kunduz within minutes of German Chancellor Angela Merkel's departure from a visit. Within two years, the German presence would be doubled and additional reinforcements from the American ISAF contingent
paraphrase: This passage discusses the events that occurred in Northern Afghanistan from April 2009 to 2014. Although this region had been relatively peaceful compared to the war-torn areas in the south and east, tensions escalated in 2008 when German soldiers stationed in the area were attacked more frequently, resulting in the deaths of several soldiers. Due to the deteriorating security situation, the German-led Regional Command North initiated a series of operations to combat the growing insurgency, which had previously been hindered by national caveats. These operations began after an insurgent attack on PRT Kunduz, which occurred just minutes after German Chancellor Angela Merkel's departure from a visit. Within two years, the German presence in the area was doubled, and additional reinforcements were provided by the American ISAF contingent.

title: Cyclone Gabrielle
input: Severe Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle was a severe tropical cyclone that devastated the North Island of New Zealand and affected parts of Vanuatu and Australia in February 2023. It is the costliest tropical cyclone on record in the Southern Hemisphere, with total damages estimated to be at least NZ$13.5 billion (US$8.4 billion), of which the provisional cost of insured damage is at least NZ$1.15 billion (US$730 million). It was also the deadliest cyclone and weather event overall to hit New Zealand since Cyclone Giselle in 1968, surpassing Cyclone Bola in 1988. The fifth named storm of the 2022–23 Australian region cyclone season, and the first severe tropical cyclone of the 2022–23 South Pacific cyclone season, Gabrielle was first noted as a developing tropical low on 6 February 2023, while
paraphrase: In February 2023, Severe Tropical Cyclone Gabrielle caused extensive damage to the North Island of New Zealand and impacted parts of Vanuatu and Australia. It holds the record for the most expensive tropical cyclone in the Southern Hemisphere, with damages estimated to be at least NZ$13.5 billion (US$8.4 billion), and insured damages at NZ$1.15 billion (US$730 million). Gabrielle was also the deadliest cyclone and weather event in New Zealand since Cyclone Giselle in 1968, surpassing Cyclone Bola in 1988. It was the fifth named storm of the 2022-23 Australian region cyclone season and the first severe tropical cyclone of the 2022-23 South Pacific cyclone season. Gabrielle was first identified as a developing tropical low on February 6, 2023.

title: 2023 Berlin repeat state election
input: The 2023 Berlin repeat state election was held on 12 February 2023 to once again elect the 19th Abgeordnetenhaus of Berlin. The 19th Abgeordnetenhaus was originally elected on 26 September 2021. On 16 November 2022, the Constitutional Court of the State of Berlin declared the results invalid due to numerous irregularities and ordered a repeat election within 90 days. A decision by the Federal Constitutional Court regarding five constitutional complaints is still pending, but will not be decided until after the repeat election. The incumbent government was a coalition of the Social Democratic Party (SPD), The Greens, and The Left led by Governing Mayor Franziska Giffey. Alongside the Abgeordnetenhaus election, the borough council results were also ruled invalid and repeat elections ordered for the same date.With 28% of
paraphrase: the vote, the Social Democratic Party (SPD), The Greens, and The Left coalition led by Governing Mayor Franziska Giffey won the 19th Abgeordnetenhaus of Berlin election on 26 September 2021. However, on 16 November 2022, the Constitutional Court of the State of Berlin declared the election results invalid due to various irregularities and ordered a repeat election to be held within 90 days. Although the Federal Constitutional Court is yet to decide on five constitutional complaints, the repeat election will take place before the decision. The borough council results were also deemed invalid, and repeat elections were scheduled for the same date.

title: 2023 Summer Metro Manila Film Festival
input: The 2023 Summer Metro Manila Film Festival is an ongoing iteration of the annual Summer Metro Manila Film Festival held in Metro Manila and throughout the Philippines. It is to be organized by the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority (MMDA) in partnership with the Cinema Exhibitors Association of the Philippines. The theme of the film festival would be "Tuloy-tuloy ang Saya" (lit. 'The fun continues').The inaugural edition was supposed to be held in 2020, but was cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The 2023 edition is now considered to be the first iteration of the film festival. Following the organization of the 2022 Metro Manila Film Festival, the MMDA announced on January 9, 2023, that the summer film festival will be held from April 8 to 18, 2023. The

Originally scheduled for 2020, the festival was cancelled due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and the 2023 edition is now considered the first iteration. The MMDA announced on January 9, 2023, that the festival will take place from April 8 to 18, 2023, following the organization of the 2022 Metro Manila Film Festival.

title: Global Pact for the Environment
input: The Global Pact for the Environment project was launched in 2017 by a network of experts known as the "International Group of Experts for the Pact" (IGEP). The group is made up of more than a hundred legal experts in environmental law and is chaired by former COP21 President Laurent Fabius.On 10 May 2018, the United Nations General Assembly adopted, by 142 votes in favor, 5 votes against (United States, Russia, Syria, Turkey, and the Philippines) and 7 abstentions (Saudi Arabia, Belarus, Iran, Malaysia, Nicaragua, Nigeria, and Tajikistan), a resolution paving the way for the negotiation of a Global Pact for the Environment (Resolution A/72/L.51 of 10 May 2018, "Towards a Global Pact for the Environment").On 8 May 2020, the United Nations Environment Programme nominated two co-facilitators to
paraphrase: In 2017, the "International Group of Experts for the Pact" (IGEP), consisting of over a hundred legal experts in environmental law and chaired by former COP21 President Laurent Fabius, launched the Global Pact for the Environment project. On May 10, 2018, the United Nations General Assembly approved a resolution, with 142 votes in favor, 5 against (United States, Russia, Syria, Turkey, and the Philippines), and 7 abstentions (Saudi Arabia, Belarus, Iran, Malaysia, Nicaragua, Nigeria, and Tajikistan), to initiate negotiations for a Global Pact for the Environment. On May 8, 2020, the United Nations Environment Programme appointed two co-facilitators for the project.

title: 2014 Conference of Western Balkan States, Berlin
input: Conference of Western Balkan States was a 28 August 2014 conference of heads of states and governments of Western Balkans region initiated by German chancellor Angela Merkel. An idea for organization of conference came in light of the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the beginning of World War I. It is the first conference in this framework and organizers expressed their desire to continue it in future with Vienna and Paris mentioned as a potential next hosts after Berlin (so called Berlin Process). Günther Oettinger confirmed at conference that event will be organised annually with Vienna as a host city in 2015 and Paris in 2016.The German chancellor announced intention to organize a conference on 7 June 2014. Invitation for participation was sent to all the countries
paraphrase: The Conference of Western Balkan States was initiated by German Chancellor Angela Merkel on 28 August 2014, bringing together heads of states and governments from the Western Balkans region. The idea for the conference was sparked by the commemoration of the 100th anniversary of the start of World War I. This was the first conference of its kind, and the organizers expressed their desire to continue it in the future, with Vienna and Paris being mentioned as potential hosts after Berlin (known as the Berlin Process). Günther Oettinger confirmed at the conference that the event would be held annually, with Vienna hosting in 2015 and Paris in 2016. The German Chancellor announced the intention to hold the conference on 7 June 2014, and invitations were sent to all participating countries.

title: 19th Empire Awards
input: The 19th Empire Awards ceremony (officially known as the Jameson Empire Awards), presented by the British film magazine Empire, honored the best films of 2013 and took place on 30 March 2014 at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London, England. During the ceremony, Empire presented Empire Awards in 14 categories as well as five honorary awards. The awards for Best Best Supporting Actor and Best Supporting Actress were first introduced this year. To celebrate the 25th anniversary of Empire magazine two special honorary awards were presented, the Action Hero of our Lifetime and the Legend of our Lifetime awards. Irish actor James Nesbitt hosted the show for the first time. The awards were sponsored by Jameson Irish Whiskey for the sixth consecutive year.In related events, Empire and Jameson
paraphrase: The Jameson Empire Awards, also known as the 19th Empire Awards, were held on March 30, 2014, at the Grosvenor House Hotel in London, England. The awards ceremony, presented by British film magazine Empire, recognized the best films of 2013 and featured 14 categories and five honorary awards. This year, the awards for Best Supporting Actor and Best Supporting Actress were introduced. Additionally, two special honorary awards were presented to celebrate the 25th anniversary of Empire magazine: the Action Hero of our Lifetime and the Legend of our Lifetime awards. James Nesbitt, an Irish actor, hosted the show for the first time, and the awards were sponsored by Jameson Irish Whiskey for the sixth consecutive year. Empire and Jameson also hosted related events.

title: Night of Champions (2023)
input: The 2023 Night of Champions is the upcoming 10th Night of Champions professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) and livestreaming event produced by the American promotion WWE. It will be held for wrestlers from the promotion's Raw and SmackDown brand divisions. The event is scheduled to be held on Saturday, May 27, 2023, at the Jeddah Super Dome in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia. This will be the first Night of Champions held on a Saturday and the first held in Saudi Arabia, subsequently being the ninth event that WWE will hold in the country under a 10-year partnership in support of Saudi Vision 2030. The previous theme of Night of Champions was that all main roster championships were contested at the event, but it is unclear if that theme will carry

This will be the 10th Night of Champions event and the first to be held on a Saturday and in Saudi Arabia. Wrestlers from the Raw and SmackDown brand divisions will participate in the event, which is part of WWE's 10-year partnership in support of Saudi Vision 2030. title: Role of Georgia in the War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)
input: Georgia joined the war in Afghanistan in 2004 and the country had become the largest non-NATO and the largest per capita troop contributor to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan by late 2012, with over 1,560 personnel on the ground as of May 2013. At its peak deployment, Georgia provided two full infantry battalions serving with the United States forces in the Helmand province. Since the beginning of their mission, more than 11,000 Georgian soldiers have served in Afghanistan.The Georgian mission in Helmand ended in July 2014. In December 2014, Georgia pledged about 750 troops to the new NATO-led non-combat, training, advisory, and assistance Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. At various times, the country has also deployed an infantry company serving with the French contingent in Kabul,
paraphrase: In 2004, Georgia entered the war in Afghanistan and by late 2012, it had become the largest non-NATO and per capita troop contributor to the International Security Assistance Force in Afghanistan, with over 1,560 personnel on the ground as of May 2013. At its highest deployment, Georgia provided two full infantry battalions serving with the United States forces in the Helmand province. Over 11,000 Georgian soldiers have served in Afghanistan since the start of their mission. The Georgian mission in Helmand ended in July 2014, but in December of that year, Georgia committed around 750 troops to the new NATO-led non-combat, training, advisory, and assistance Resolute Support Mission in Afghanistan. Additionally, at different times, the country has sent an infantry company to serve with the French contingent in Kabul.

title: 2014 Colombian parliamentary election
input: Parliamentary elections were held in Colombia on 9 March 2014 to elect members to both chambers of Congress. The nationwide constituency for the 102-member Senate was contested, as well as the 166 seats of the House of Representatives, plus the delegates to the Andean Parliament. There were 773 candidates for the Senate, 1,528 candidates for the House of Representatives, and 23 candidates for the five Colombian seats in the Andean Parliament. 32,795,962 Colombians had been registered to vote in the elections by the cut-off date of 25 January 2014.The elections were notable for the decision by former president Álvaro Uribe to stand for the Senate, the first ex-president in modern Colombian history to run for Congress afterwards. Uribe is constitutionally barred from standing for president again, having already
paraphrase: On 9 March 2014, Colombia held parliamentary elections to select members for both chambers of Congress. The Senate, which has 102 members, and the House of Representatives, which has 166 seats, were both contested in a nationwide constituency. Additionally, delegates to the Andean Parliament were also elected. There were a total of 773 candidates for the Senate, 1,528 candidates for the House of Representatives, and 23 candidates for the five Colombian seats in the Andean Parliament. As of 25 January 2014, 32,795,962 Colombians were registered to vote in the elections. The elections were noteworthy because former president Álvaro Uribe decided to run for the Senate, making him the first ex-president in modern Colombian history to do so. Uribe is constitutionally prohibited from running for president again, having already served two terms.

title: Before the Dawn (Kate Bush concert residency)
input: Before the Dawn was a concert residency by the English singer-songwriter Kate Bush in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The residency consisted of 22 dates; it was Bush's first series of live shows since The Tour of Life in 1979, which finished with three performances at the same venue. A live recording of the same name was released in physical and digital formats in November 2016.On 21 March 2014, Bush announced via her website her plans to perform live. Pre-sale tickets were on sale for fans who had signed up to her website and an additional seven dates were added to the original 15, due to the high demand. Tickets were on sale to the general public on 28 March and were sold out within 15
paraphrase: Kate Bush, an English singer-songwriter, held a concert residency called "Before the Dawn" in 2014 at the Hammersmith Apollo in London. The residency included 22 shows and marked Bush's first live performances since her "Tour of Life" in 1979, which ended with three shows at the same venue. A live recording of the residency was released in November 2016. Bush announced her plans to perform live on her website on March 21, 2014, and pre-sale tickets were available to fans who had signed up on her website. Due to high demand, seven additional dates were added to the original 15. General public tickets went on sale on March 28 and sold out within 15 minutes.

title: Chang'e 5-T1
input: Chang'e 5-T1 (Chinese: 嫦娥五号T1; pinyin: Cháng'é wǔhào T1) was an experimental robotic spacecraft that was launched to the Moon on 23 October 2014, by the China National Space Administration (CNSA) to conduct atmospheric re-entry tests on the capsule design planned to be used in the Chang'e 5 mission. As part of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program, Chang'e 5, launched in 2020, was a Moon sample return mission. Like its predecessors, the spacecraft is named after the Chinese Moon goddess Chang'e. The craft consisted of a return vehicle capsule and a service module orbiter.The return capsule of Chang'e 5-T1, named Xiaofei (Chinese: 小飞), meaning "little flyer" in Chinese, landed in Siziwang Banner, Inner Mongolia, on 31 October 2014, 22:42 UTC. The CE-5-T1 Service Module entered lunar orbit on 13
paraphrase: Chang'e 5-T1, a robotic spacecraft launched by the China National Space Administration on 23 October 2014, was an experimental mission designed to test the capsule's atmospheric re-entry capabilities for the upcoming Chang'e 5 mission. The latter was part of the Chinese Lunar Exploration Program and aimed to collect samples from the Moon. The spacecraft was named after the Chinese Moon goddess Chang'e and consisted of a return vehicle capsule and a service module orbiter. The return capsule, named Xiaofei, landed in Inner Mongolia on 31 October 2014, while the service module entered lunar orbit on 13.

title: 2014 Sundarbans oil spill
input: The 2014 Sundarbans oil spill was an oil spill that occurred on 9 December 2014 at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The spill occurred when an oil-tanker named Southern Star VII, carrying 350,000 litres (77,000 imp gal; 92,000 US gal) of furnace oil, was in collision with a cargo vessel and sank in the river. By 17 December, the oil had spread over a 350 km2 (140 sq mi) area. The oil spread to a second river and a network of canals in Sundarbans, which blackened the shoreline. The spill threatened trees, plankton, and vast populations of small fish and dolphins. The spill occurred at a protected mangrove area, home to rare Irrawaddy and Ganges river dolphins. By 12 January 2015, 70,000
paraphrase: In December 2014, an oil spill took place at the Shela River in Sundarbans, Bangladesh, which is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The spill happened when a ship called Southern Star VII, carrying 350,000 litres of furnace oil, collided with a cargo vessel and sank in the river. The oil spread over an area of 350 km2 by 17 December, affecting a second river and a network of canals in Sundarbans. The spill caused damage to trees, plankton, and a large number of small fish and dolphins. The area where the spill occurred is a protected mangrove region, which is home to rare Irrawaddy and Ganges river dolphins. As of 12 January 2015, 70,000 people were involved in the cleanup efforts.

title: 2022–2023 Irish anti-immigration protests
input: Protests at several locations in Ireland started in early November 2022 after the development of sites in various parts of the country as temporary refugee shelters by the Department of Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth (DCEDIY), as it attempts to accommodate the influx of 65,000 refugees during 2022. Protests have been held in East Wall, Ballymun, Drimnagh and elsewhere in Dublin, Fermoy and Mallow in County Cork, Kill, County Kildare, Lismore, County Waterford, and Mullingar. The protests raised similar concerns over refugee selection discrimination and the lack of provision of prior information to residents. Protesters have questioned the lack of women and children in some accommodation centres.The presence of anti-immigrant protesters, members of far-right groups, and violent criminals at these protests has been highlighted online and in
paraphrase: In early November 2022, protests erupted in various locations across Ireland due to the Department of Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth's (DCEDIY) decision to develop temporary refugee shelters in different parts of the country to accommodate the influx of 65,000 refugees in 2022. The protests took place in Dublin (East Wall, Ballymun, Drimnagh), County Cork (Fermoy, Mallow), County Kildare (Kill), County Waterford (Lismore), and Mullingar. The protesters expressed similar concerns about refugee selection discrimination and the lack of information provided to residents beforehand. They also questioned the absence of women and children in some of the accommodation centers. Online and in-person, the presence of anti-immigrant protesters, far-right group members, and violent criminals at these protests has been highlighted.

title: 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina
input: The 2014 unrest in Bosnia and Herzegovina was a series of demonstrations and riots that began in the northern town of Tuzla on 4 February 2014 but quickly spread to multiple cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko, among others, for social reasons and with the aim of overthrowing the government. The riots were the most violent scenes the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The rioting largely took place in the entity of Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, and the same level of unrest or activism did not occur in Republika Srpska.Some news sources, such as BBC and The New York Times, used the name Bosnian Spring when describing the riots, a terminology taken from other
paraphrase: The unrest that occurred in Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2014 consisted of a series of protests and riots that began in Tuzla on February 4th and quickly spread to other cities in the country, including Sarajevo, Zenica, Mostar, Jajce, and Brčko. The aim of the protests was to overthrow the government due to social reasons. These riots were the most violent the country had seen since the end of the Bosnian War in 1995. The majority of the unrest occurred in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina, with Republika Srpska experiencing less activism. Some news sources referred to the riots as the Bosnian Spring, a term borrowed from other sources.

title: 2023 German public transport strike
input: The 2023 German public transport strike was a nationwide labor strike that occurred in March 2023 in Germany. The strike was organized by Ver.di and EVG, two major transport unions, who demanded a 10.5% pay increase for their members to offset rising food and energy costs. This strike was one of the largest to affect Germany in decades and impacted airports - including those in Munich, Frankfurt, and Hamburg - public transport, and the country's largest seaport. Railroad services, as well as early morning regional and commuter rail services, were suspended throughout the country.The strike involved over 400,000 transport workers, making it the largest transport workers' action since a series of strikes in the 1990s. Its aim was to serve as a warning to the government and employers
paraphrase: In March 2023, a nationwide labor strike took place in Germany, known as the 2023 German public transport strike. The strike was organized by two major transport unions, Ver.di and EVG, who demanded a 10.5% pay increase for their members due to the increasing costs of food and energy. This strike was one of the largest to affect Germany in decades and had a significant impact on airports, public transport, and the country's largest seaport, including the suspension of railroad services and early morning regional and commuter rail services throughout the country. With over 400,000 transport workers involved, it was the largest transport workers' action since a series of strikes in the 1990s. The strike aimed to serve as a warning to the government and employers.

title: Disappearance of Lars Mittank
input: Lars Joachim Mittank (born February 9, 1986) is a German man who disappeared on July 8, 2014, near Varna Airport in Varna, Bulgaria. Mittank was vacationing at the Golden Sands resort, where he was supposedly involved in a fight, and was subsequently unable to fly home with his friends for health reasons. Mittank was documented acting strangely while alone in Bulgaria. He called home to his mother claiming that people were trying to kill him. On the day when he was supposed to fly home, Mittank went to the Varna Airport to consult with a doctor. He was later seen on airport security footage running out of the airport and towards an adjacent forest. He has never been seen since. The case has generated intense interest, and the

While on vacation at the Golden Sands resort, Mittank was allegedly involved in a physical altercation, which prevented him from returning home with his companions due to health concerns. Mittank's behavior in Bulgaria was peculiar, and he contacted his mother, claiming that he was being targeted for assassination. On the day of his scheduled departure, Mittank visited a doctor at Varna Airport, but he was later captured on airport surveillance footage running towards a nearby forest, and he has not been seen since. The case has sparked significant interest and attention.

title: Willis Resilience Expedition
input: The Willis Resilience Expedition was a scientific and exploratory program that took place in Antarctica from November 2013 to January 2014, with the goal of a better understanding of changes in the Earth's climate brought on by global warming in addition to weather-related risk. Announced in August 2013, the expedition was led by explorer Douglas Stoup and Parker Liautaud, a teenage polar adventurer and environmental campaigner. The expedition was underwritten by Willis Group, a global risk advisor, insurance and reinsurance broker. The communications team, including driver and mechanic Eyjo Furteitsson, communication manager Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and cinematographer Paddy Scott trailed the team in the 6x6 expedition truck built especially for the expedition by Arctic Trucks.The expedition consisted of three main components: Science. Liautaud and Stoup conducted an isotope transect
paraphrase: The Willis Resilience Expedition was a scientific and exploratory mission that occurred in Antarctica between November 2013 and January 2014. Its primary objective was to gain a better understanding of the effects of global warming on the Earth's climate and weather-related risks. The expedition was announced in August 2013 and was led by polar adventurer and environmental campaigner Parker Liautaud and explorer Douglas Stoup. It was sponsored by Willis Group, a global risk advisor, insurance, and reinsurance broker. The team was accompanied by a communications crew, including driver and mechanic Eyjo Furteitsson, communication manager Nathan Hambrook-Skinner, and cinematographer Paddy Scott, who followed them in a specially built 6x6 expedition truck from Arctic Trucks. The expedition had three main components, including scientific research, which involved conducting an isotope transect.

title: Cold Water Flat
input: Cold Water Flat was an American band formed in 1990 by Paul Janovitz (vocals and guitar), Ted Silva (bass) and Paul Harding (drums) when the trio studied at University of Massachusetts Amherst. Paul Janovitz is the younger brother of Bill Janovitz, lead singer and songwriter of Buffalo Tom. They began playing shows in Boston before Janovitz moved to New York; the group nearly split up, but when European label Play It Again Sam offered to release an album, they reconsidered. In 1995, they signed with MCA Records and released a self-titled second album, recorded at Fort Apache Studios, but despite getting some airplay mainly in US college radio stations the band did not reach a wider audience. Soon after the group disbanded, Janovitz went on to join Dragstrip
paraphrase: Cold Water Flat was a band that originated in the United States in 1990, consisting of Paul Janovitz (vocals and guitar), Ted Silva (bass), and Paul Harding (drums), who all attended the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Buffalo Tom's lead singer and songwriter, Bill Janovitz, is Paul Janovitz's younger brother. They began performing in Boston, but when Janovitz relocated to New York, the group almost broke up. However, they reconsidered when Play It Again Sam, a European label, offered to release an album. In 1995, they signed with MCA Records and released a self-titled second album, which was recorded at Fort Apache Studios. Despite receiving some airplay, mainly on US college radio stations, the band did not gain a wider audience. The group disbanded shortly after, and Janovitz went on to join Dragstrip.

title: 2014 Brazilian economic crisis
input: From mid-2014 onward, Brazil experienced a severe economic crisis. The country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) fell by 3.5% in 2015 and 3.3% in 2016, after which a small economic recovery began. That recovery continued until 2020, when the COVID-19 pandemic began to impact the economy again. The economic crisis occurred alongside a political crisis that resulted in the impeachment of president Dilma Rousseff. These events combined caused mass popular dissatisfaction with the political system. The cause of the crisis was the aforementioned political crisis, as well as the 2014 commodity price shock, which negatively affected Brazil's exports and reduced the entrance of foreign capital into the economy. However, the most important cause was internal, which is associated with economic measures that didn't achieve the expected results. Adopted in
paraphrase: the mid-2014, Brazil faced a severe economic downturn, with a 3.5% and 3.3% decline in GDP in 2015 and 2016, respectively. The country saw a slight economic recovery until the COVID-19 pandemic hit in 2020. The economic crisis was compounded by a political crisis that led to the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff, resulting in widespread dissatisfaction with the political system. The crisis was caused by the political turmoil, the 2014 commodity price shock, which impacted exports and foreign investment, and internal economic measures that failed to deliver the expected outcomes.

title: Global news flow
input: Global news flow (also referred to as international news flow) is a field of study that deals with the news coverage of events in foreign countries. It describes and explains the flow of news from one country to another.Studies on global news flow typically attempt to understand why certain countries are more newsworthy than others.. Along the years it has been found that the economic power of countries plays a particularly crucial role in their news prominence as well as the presence of international news agencies. Thus, the US has been found to be very prominent in news mentions around the world (18%), followed by China, Western European and Middle Eastern countries (about 3-5% each).The unequal representation of the world and the under-representation of developing countries have been
paraphrase: Global news flow, also known as international news flow, is a field of research that focuses on the reporting of events in foreign nations. It aims to describe and clarify how news travels from one country to another. Studies on global news flow aim to comprehend why some countries receive more news coverage than others. Over time, it has been discovered that a country's economic power and the presence of international news agencies are critical factors in determining its news prominence. As a result, the United States is the most frequently mentioned country in news worldwide (18%), followed by China, Western European, and Middle Eastern countries (approximately 3-5% each). The unequal representation of the world and the under-representation of developing countries are significant issues in this field.

title: 2023 Jenin incursion
input: On 26 January 2023, the Israel Border Police and the Israeli army conducted an armed raid on the Jenin refugee camp, which is in Area A of the Israeli-occupied West Bank and under Palestinian civil authority. According to The Jerusalem Post, the objective was to prevent a planned terrorist strike and arrest three wanted Islamic Jihad militants.Nine Palestinians were killed by Israeli forces during the ensuing clashes, one of whom was an elderly woman. On 29 January, another Palestinian succumbed to wounds received during the raid, bringing the total killed to ten. It was the deadliest Israeli raid on the Jenin refugee camp in nearly 20 years. The Israeli government said at least six of those killed were armed men. The deaths brought the number of Palestinians killed
paraphrase: During an armed operation on 26 January 2023, the Israeli Border Police and army conducted a raid on the Jenin refugee camp, located in Area A of the West Bank, which is under Palestinian civil authority. The aim of the operation, according to The Jerusalem Post, was to prevent a planned terrorist attack and apprehend three Islamic Jihad militants who were wanted by Israeli authorities. As a result of the ensuing clashes, nine Palestinians were killed by Israeli forces, including an elderly woman. Another Palestinian died from injuries sustained during the raid on 29 January, bringing the total number of fatalities to ten. This was the deadliest Israeli raid on the Jenin refugee camp in almost two decades. The Israeli government claimed that at least six of those killed were armed men. The number of Palestinians killed in the operation increased as a result of these deaths.

title: 2023 vote of no confidence in the government of Pedro Sánchez
input: A motion of no confidence in the Spanish government of Pedro Sánchez was tabled by the far-right party Vox on 27 February 2023, and will be debated and voted in the Congress of Deputies between 21 and 22 March 2023. It was the sixth motion of no confidence in Spain since the country's transition to democracy.Vox announced the motion of no confidence on 9 December 2022, proposing it to be tabled under an independent candidate with government experience, voicing that Sánchez's proposed reforms of the Criminal Code to modify the embezzlement and sedition crimes were akin to a "self-coup" similar to "that of Pedro Castillo in Peru" two days earlier. The opposition People's Party (PP) under Alberto Núñez Feijóo stated that it would not vote against the motion,
paraphrase: The far-right party Vox has put forward a motion of no confidence against the Spanish government led by Pedro Sánchez. The motion will be discussed and voted on in the Congress of Deputies on 21-22 March 2023. This is the sixth motion of no confidence in Spain since the country's transition to democracy. Vox proposed the motion on 9 December 2022, suggesting an independent candidate with government experience to lead it. They argued that Sánchez's proposed reforms to the Criminal Code, which would modify embezzlement and sedition crimes, were similar to a "self-coup" like that of Pedro Castillo in Peru. The opposition People's Party (PP) under Alberto Núñez Feijóo has stated that it will not vote against the motion.

title: 2023 Israeli municipal elections
input: Municipal elections are set to be held in Israel on 31 October 2023. In accordance with changes made in 2018, election day will be a paid day off work. All municipalities, local councils and regional councils will be up for election, as will their leaders. Top-two runoffs will be held on 14 November in all localities where no leadership candidate won 40% or more of the vote in the first round.Voters in municipalities and local councils will pick their leader and council in two separate ballots that will be colored yellow and white respectively. Voters in regional councils will also vote for a local committee using ballots that are colored blue. blue ballots will also be used for borough committees in cases in which they exist. All elected
paraphrase: officials in municipalities, local councils, and regional councils will be chosen through the upcoming municipal elections in Israel, which are scheduled for 31 October 2023. As per the changes implemented in 2018, election day will be a paid holiday. In the event that no leadership candidate secures 40% or more of the vote in the first round, a top-two runoff will be held on 14 November in all localities. Voters will cast their ballots for their preferred leader and council in separate yellow and white ballots, respectively, in municipalities and local councils. Meanwhile, blue ballots will be used for regional councils and borough committees, if applicable. All elected officials will be determined through this election process.

title: Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión
input: The Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station) or Union Glacier Station is a summer Antarctic base of Chile, situated on Union Glacier in the Ellsworth Mountains. It is jointly operated from November to January by the Chilean Antarctic Institute and the three armed forces of Chile. It was inaugurated on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique.In 2013, the Antarctic stations Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus were dismantled and their equipment was transferred to Union Glacier Station. This followed the relocation in November 2010 of the operations of the private American company Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC, which has operated the landing strip on Union Glacier since December 2008 and also runs Union Glacier Camp.After the American
paraphrase: company Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC moved its operations to Union Glacier in November 2010, the Estación Polar Científica Conjunta Glaciar Unión (or Union Glacier Joint Scientific Polar Station) was established as a summer Antarctic base of Chile. It is located on Union Glacier in the Ellsworth Mountains and is jointly operated by the Chilean Antarctic Institute and the three armed forces of Chile from November to January. The station was inaugurated on 4 January 2014 by Chilean President Sebastián Piñera Echeñique. In 2013, the equipment from the dismantled Antarctic stations Teniente Arturo Parodi Alister and Antonio Huneeus was transferred to Union Glacier Station. Additionally, the private American company Antarctic Logistics & Expeditions LLC runs Union Glacier Camp.

title: 2014 DFB-Pokal final
input: The 2014 DFB-Pokal Final decided the winner of the 2013–14 DFB-Pokal, the 71st season of Germany's premier football cup. It was played on 17 May at the Olympiastadion in Berlin. In the final, Borussia Dortmund played Bayern Munich. The winners would have earned a place in the group stage of the 2014–15 UEFA Europa League, but both teams had already qualified for the 2014–15 UEFA Champions League via their league positions. Because of this, the three Europa League spots were passed down through league positions. This was the last season in which the cup runners-up would have qualified for the Europa League if the winners had already qualified for the Champions League. The winners also earned the right to play in the 2014 DFL-Supercup; as Bayern had already
paraphrase: The 71st season of Germany's top football cup, the DFB-Pokal, was decided in the 2014 final held on May 17th at the Olympiastadion in Berlin between Borussia Dortmund and Bayern Munich. The victorious team would have secured a spot in the group stage of the 2014-15 UEFA Europa League, but both teams had already qualified for the 2014-15 UEFA Champions League through their league positions. As a result, the three Europa League spots were given to teams based on their league positions. This was the last season in which the runners-up of the cup would have qualified for the Europa League if the winners had already qualified for the Champions League. The winners also earned the right to play in the 2014 DFL-Supercup, but Bayern had already secured their place in the match.

title: APRA Music Awards of 2023
input: The APRA Music Awards of 2023 are the upcoming 41st annual series, known as the APRA Awards. The awards are given in a series of categories in three divisions and in separate ceremonies throughout the year: the APRA Music Awards, Art Music Awards and Screen Music Awards. The APRA Music Awards are provided by APRA AMCOS (Australasian Performing Right Association and Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society) and celebrate excellence in contemporary music, honouring songwriters and publishers that have achieved artistic excellence and outstanding success in their fields. In January, 20 songs shortlisted for Song of the Year were announced. On 30 March 2023, the final nominations were provided. Winners of the 2023 Ted Albert Award for Outstanding Services to Australian Music were Colin Hay and Colleen Ironside. APRA

The APRA Music Awards are organized by APRA AMCOS, which stands for Australasian Performing Right Association and Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society. These awards recognize excellence in contemporary music and honor songwriters and publishers who have achieved artistic excellence and outstanding success in their respective fields. In January, a list of 20 songs was announced as shortlisted for the Song of the Year award. The final nominations were revealed on March 30, 2023. Colin Hay and Colleen Ironside were the recipients of the 2023 Ted Albert Award for Outstanding Services to Australian Music.

title: Delhi–Kathmandu Bus
input: The Delhi-Kathmandu bus is a trans-boundary bus service connecting India and Nepal's capitals at Delhi and Kathmandu respectively. The service is operated by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) and was launched in 2014.While Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC), a state run corporation, will run the bus service from Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) is operating the bus service under supervision of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport MoPIT. Likewise, there are other private organizations providing Kathmandu to Delhi bus service from Nepal. This bus service has a 2X2 seating arrangement and is an AC bus service. The service operates from Dr. Ambedkar bus stand near Delhi gate in Delhi. This bus travels via Agra (by Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow,Ayodhyaand Gorakhpur in India.

The service was established in 2014 and is managed by the Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC). While the DTC oversees the bus service from the Indian side, the Federation of Nepalese National Transport Entrepreneurs (FNNTE) operates it under the supervision of the Ministry of Physical Infrastructure and Transport MoPIT. Additionally, there are private organizations that offer bus services from Kathmandu to Delhi in Nepal. The bus service features a 2X2 seating arrangement and is air-conditioned. It departs from Dr. Ambedkar bus stand near Delhi gate in Delhi and travels through Agra (via Yamuna Expressway), Firozabad, Kanpur, Lucknow, Ayodhya, and Gorakhpur in India.

title: Internet anomalies in mainland China in 2014
input: In the afternoon of January 21, 2014, the Chinese internet suffered a major failure. The country's DNS infrastructure, which is responsible for translating domain names into IP addresses, started directing unrelated domains from various TLDs to the completely unresponsive IP address 65.49.2.178 at 15:10 (UTC+8). As a result, two-thirds of all domestic websites became non-functional, including such high-traffic sites as Baidu and Sina.It is debated what caused this incident. Chinese officials point to the fact that the IP address is owned by Dynamic Internet Technology, an American Falun Gong-affiliated corporation most known for developing the Great Firewall circumvention tool Freegate, and argue that it was caused by external hacking. Independent researchers, however, argue that the incident is more likely caused by a misconfiguration in Great Firewall's DNS poisoning
paraphrase: On January 21, 2014, there was a significant failure in the Chinese internet during the afternoon. The DNS infrastructure responsible for translating domain names into IP addresses began directing unrelated domains from various TLDs to an unresponsive IP address, 65.49.2.178, at 15:10 (UTC+8). This caused two-thirds of all domestic websites, including popular sites like Baidu and Sina, to become non-functional. The cause of the incident is debated, with Chinese officials suggesting external hacking due to the IP address being owned by Dynamic Internet Technology, an American corporation affiliated with Falun Gong and known for developing the Great Firewall circumvention tool Freegate. However, independent researchers believe that a misconfiguration in the Great Firewall's DNS poisoning is more likely to have caused the incident.

title: 54th NAACP Image Awards
input: The 54th NAACP Image Awards, presented by the NAACP, honored outstanding representations and achievements of people of color in motion pictures, television, music, and literature during the 2022 calendar year. The ceremony was hosted by Queen Latifah and aired on February 25, 2023, on BET and simulcast on several of its sister Paramount Global Networks along with Paramount+. Presentations of untelevised categories was livestreamed from February 20 to February 24, 2023, on the ceremony's website.The nominations were announced on January 12, 2023, with the film Black Panther: Wakanda Forever leading the nominations with twelve nods, followed by the television sitcom Abbott Elementary which led the television categories with nine nominations. In the recording categories, Beyoncé and Kendrick Lamar lead the nominations with five each. For the first time

The awards for categories that were not televised were livestreamed on the ceremony's website from February 20 to February 24, 2023. Beyoncé and Kendrick Lamar received the most nominations in the recording categories with five each.

title: Malindi cult
input: The Good News International Ministries (GNIM), commonly known as the Malindi cult and previously as the Servant P. N. Mackenzie Ministries, is a new religious movement based in Shakahola, Kilifi, Kenya, that was founded by Paul Nthenge Mackenzie and his wife in 2003. Though often listed as a Christian organisation, many of its teachings contradict mainstream Christianity. The group attracted international attention in April 2023 when it was revealed that Mackenzie had allegedly instructed members to starve themselves en masse to "meet Jesus", resulting in the deaths of at least 110 people. The group, often described as a cult, is adamantly anti-Western, with amenities such as health care, education, and sports being dismissed as "evils of western life" and with Mackenzie condemning the United States, the United Nations,
paraphrase:
and other Western institutions.

The Malindi cult, also known as the Good News International Ministries (GNIM), is a recently established religious movement located in Shakahola, Kilifi, Kenya. It was founded by Paul Nthenge Mackenzie and his wife in 2003 and is often categorized as a Christian organization, despite its teachings contradicting mainstream Christianity. The group gained global attention in April 2023 when it was revealed that Mackenzie had allegedly instructed members to starve themselves en masse to "meet Jesus," leading to the deaths of at least 110 individuals. The group is frequently referred to as a cult and is strongly opposed to Western culture, dismissing amenities such as healthcare, education, and sports as "evils of western life." Mackenzie also condemns Western institutions such as the United States and the United Nations.

title: 80th Golden Globe Awards
input: The 80th Golden Globe Awards honored the best in film and American television of 2022, as chosen by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association (HFPA). The ceremony was held on January 10, 2023, from The Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills, California, produced by Dick Clark Productions and the HFPA, and aired live in the United States on NBC and streamed on Peacock. Jerrod Carmichael hosted the ceremony.The nominees were announced on December 12, 2022. Father-daughter duo George and Mayan Lopez were scheduled to announce the nominations together, but the former dropped out after testing positive for COVID-19; he was replaced by Selenis Leyva. Eddie Murphy and Ryan Murphy were announced as the recipients of the Cecil B. DeMille Award and Carol Burnett Award, respectively. The Banshees of Inisherin received

It was broadcasted live on NBC and streamed on Peacock. Jerrod Carmichael hosted the event. The nominees were revealed on December 12, 2022. title: 2013–2014 Israeli–Palestinian peace talks
input: The 2013–2014 Israeli–Palestinian peace talks were part of the Israeli–Palestinian peace process. Direct negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians began on 29 July 2013 following an attempt by United States Secretary of State John Kerry to restart the peace process. Martin Indyk of the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. was appointed by the US to oversee the negotiations. Indyk served as U.S. ambassador to Israel and assistant secretary of state for Near East affairs during the Clinton administration. Hamas, the Palestinian government in Gaza, rejected Kerry's announcement, stating that Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas has no legitimacy to negotiate in the name of the Palestinian people.The negotiations were scheduled to last up to nine months to reach a final status to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict by mid-2014. The Israeli negotiating
paraphrase: The Israeli-Palestinian peace talks that took place in 2013-2014 were a part of the larger Israeli-Palestinian peace process. These talks were initiated by United States Secretary of State John Kerry in an effort to restart the peace process. Direct negotiations between Israel and Palestine began on July 29, 2013, with Martin Indyk of the Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. appointed by the US to oversee the negotiations. Hamas, the Palestinian government in Gaza, rejected Kerry's announcement, claiming that Palestinian president Mahmoud Abbas lacked legitimacy to negotiate on behalf of the Palestinian people. The negotiations were intended to last up to nine months, with the goal of reaching a final resolution to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict by mid-2014. The Israeli negotiating team was led by Tzipi Livni, Israel's Justice Minister at the time.

title: 2023 New Hampshire bombings
input: At around 6:10 PM EDT on April 26, 2023, what was later determined to be an improvised explosive device exploded in Weare, New Hampshire at a home on NH Route 77. ATF and FBI agents responded to the scene. A second bomb exploded at 6:50 AM the next day inside a van parked along Sugar Hill Road. The driver of the van reported that he was driving when he noticed the bomb, pulled over to remove it, and it exploded in front of him, causing minor injuries. Residents within 2 miles of either bombing have been asked to review their surveillance tapes for anything suspicious.On 27 April 2023, Dale Stewart was arrested in Webster and a pipe bomb was found in his car and neutralized. He was arraigned
paraphrase: On April 26, 2023, an improvised explosive device detonated at a residence on NH Route 77 in Weare, New Hampshire, at approximately 6:10 PM EDT. The incident was investigated by ATF and FBI agents. The following day, at 6:50 AM, a second bomb exploded in a van parked on Sugar Hill Road. The driver of the van reported that he had noticed the bomb while driving, pulled over to remove it, and sustained minor injuries when it detonated in front of him. Residents within a 2-mile radius of either bombing were requested to review their surveillance footage for any suspicious activity. On April 27, 2023, Dale Stewart was apprehended in Webster, and a pipe bomb was discovered in his vehicle and rendered harmless. He was arraigned on charges.

title: Miss Belgium 2023
input: Miss Belgium 2023 was the 55th edition of the Miss Belgium pageant, held on February 11, 2023, at the Plopsaland Theater in De Panne, Belgium. Because of the absence of reigning Miss Belgium, Chayenne Van Aarle, Miss Belgium 2021 Kedist Deltour crowned Emilie Vansteenkiste of Flemish Brabant at end of the event. Vansteenkiste will represent Belgium at the Miss World 2023 pageant.The Miss Belgium organisation had to deal with misfortune starting the last week before the event. Reigning Miss Belgium, Chayenne Van Aarle, had a major car accident a few days before the event. She wasn't present at the event because she still had to recover. The event was postponed a few hours before the start because suspicions of a terrorist attack. A suspect was arrested, weapons were

Due to the absence of the reigning Miss Belgium, Chayenne Van Aarle, Kedist Deltour, Miss Belgium 2021, crowned Emilie Vansteenkiste of Flemish Brabant as the winner of the event. Vansteenkiste will represent Belgium at the Miss World 2023 pageant. Unfortunately, the Miss Belgium organization faced several challenges leading up to the event. Just days before the pageant, reigning Miss Belgium, Chayenne Van Aarle, was involved in a serious car accident and was unable to attend. Additionally, the event was delayed due to concerns of a potential terrorist attack, resulting in the arrest of a suspect and the discovery of weapons.

title: 76th British Academy Film Awards
input: The 76th British Academy Film Awards, more commonly known as the BAFTAs, were held on 19 February 2023, honouring the best national and foreign films of 2022, at the Royal Festival Hall within London's Southbank Centre. Presented by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, accolades were handed out for the best feature-length film and documentaries of any nationality that were screened at British cinemas in 2022. The nominations were announced on 19 January 2023 via a global livestream, hosted by actors Hayley Atwell and Toheeb Jimoh, from the arts charity's newly redeveloped HQ at 195 Piccadilly, London. The EE Rising Star Award nominees, which is the only category voted for by the British public, were announced on 17 January 2023.The German-language epic anti-war drama All Quiet

The event, organized by the British Academy of Film and Television Arts, recognized the best national and foreign films of 2022, including feature-length films and documentaries shown in British cinemas. The nominations were revealed on January 19, 2023 through a global livestream hosted by Hayley Atwell and Toheeb Jimoh from the charity's headquarters in London. The EE Rising Star Award nominees, the only category voted on by the British public, were announced on January 17, 2023. All Quiet, a German-language epic anti-war drama, was among the nominees.

title: Opération Chammal
input: Opération Chammal is a French military operation in Iraq and Syria launched to help curtail the expansion of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant and to support the Iraqi Army. Its name comes from the Shamal (Chammal in French), a northwesterly wind that blows over Iraq and the Persian Gulf states.Airstrikes over Iraq started 19 September 2014 and airstrikes over Syria started by the end of September 2015. The French operation was at first limited to airstrikes and French president François Hollande had stated that no ground troops would be deployed in the conflict. Additionally, the French frigate Jean Bart joined the United States Navy's Commander Task Force 50 (CTF 50) as an escort.On 14 November 2015, ISIS claimed that the terrorist attacks that took place
paraphrase:
in Paris were in retaliation for France's involvement in the military operation in Iraq and Syria.

The French military launched Operation Chammal in Iraq and Syria to help stop the expansion of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant and to support the Iraqi Army. The operation's name is derived from the Shamal wind that blows over Iraq and the Persian Gulf states. Airstrikes began in September 2014 over Iraq and in September 2015 over Syria. Initially, the operation was limited to airstrikes, and the French president stated that no ground troops would be deployed. The French frigate Jean Bart joined the United States Navy's Commander Task Force 50 as an escort. On November 14, 2015, ISIS claimed responsibility for the terrorist attacks in Paris, citing France's involvement in the military operation as the reason for the attacks.

title: Argentine debt restructuring
input: The Argentine debt restructuring is a process of debt restructuring by Argentina that began on January 14, 2005, and allowed it to resume payment on 76% of the US$82 billion in sovereign bonds that defaulted in 2001 at the depth of the worst economic crisis in the nation's history. A second debt restructuring in 2010 brought the percentage of bonds under some form of repayment to 93%, though ongoing disputes with holdouts remained. Bondholders who participated in the restructuring settled for repayments of around 30% of face value and deferred payment terms, and began to be paid punctually; the value of their nearly worthless bonds also began to rise. The remaining 7% of bondholders were later repaid 25% less then they were demanding, after centre-right and US-aligned leader
paraphrase: Argentina underwent a debt restructuring process starting on January 14, 2005, which allowed the country to resume payment on 76% of the US$82 billion in sovereign bonds that had defaulted in 2001 during the nation's worst economic crisis. A second debt restructuring in 2010 increased the percentage of bonds under some form of repayment to 93%, but disputes with holdouts persisted. Those who participated in the restructuring received repayments of approximately 30% of face value and deferred payment terms, and were paid on time. The value of their previously worthless bonds also increased. The remaining 7% of bondholders were eventually repaid 25% less than their demands after a change in leadership to a centre-right and US-aligned leader.

title: Operation Car Wash
input: Operation Car Wash (Portuguese: Operação Lava Jato) was a criminal investigation by the Federal Police of Brazil's Curitiba branch. It began in March 2014 and was initially headed by investigative judge Sérgio Moro, and in 2019 by Judge Luiz Antônio Bonat. It has resulted in more than a thousand warrants of various types. According to the Operation Car Wash task force, investigations implicate administrative members of the state-owned oil company Petrobras, politicians from Brazil's largest parties (including presidents of the Republic), presidents of the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate, state governors, and businessmen from large Brazilian companies. The Federal Police consider it the largest corruption investigation in the country's history. The taskforce was officially disbanded on 1 February 2021.Originally a money laundering investigation, it expanded to

It commenced in March 2014 and was initially led by investigative judge Sérgio Moro, and later by Judge Luiz Antônio Bonat in 2019. The investigation has resulted in over a thousand warrants of various kinds. According to the Operation Car Wash task force, the probe implicates administrative members of the state-owned oil company Petrobras, politicians from Brazil's major political parties (including presidents of the Republic), presidents of the Chamber of Deputies and the Federal Senate, state governors, and businesspeople from large Brazilian corporations. The Federal Police regard it as the most extensive corruption investigation in the country's history. The task force was officially dissolved on February 1, 2021. Initially, it was a money laundering investigation that later expanded.

title: 65th Annual Grammy Awards
input: The 65th Annual Grammy Awards ceremony was a music awards ceremony held at the Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles on February 5, 2023. It recognized the best recordings, compositions, and artists of the eligibility year – October 1, 2021 to September 30, 2022 – as determined by the members of National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. The nominations were announced on November 15, 2022. South African comedian Trevor Noah, who hosted the 63rd and 64th ceremonies, returned again.Beyoncé received the most nominations (nine) and tied Maverick City Music for wins (four), followed by Kendrick Lamar with eight nominations and three wins, and Adele and Brandi Carlile with seven nominations each. With a career total of 88 nominations, Beyoncé tied with her husband Jay-Z as the most nominated
paraphrase: The 65th Annual Grammy Awards took place on February 5, 2023 at the Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles. The event recognized outstanding recordings, compositions, and artists from October 1, 2021 to September 30, 2022, as determined by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences. The nominations were announced on November 15, 2022, and the ceremony was hosted by Trevor Noah. Beyoncé received the most nominations with nine, tying with Maverick City Music for the most wins at four. Kendrick Lamar followed with eight nominations and three wins, while Adele and Brandi Carlile each received seven nominations. Beyoncé also tied with her husband Jay-Z for the most career nominations at 88.

title: 2014 Bosnian general election
input: General elections were held in Bosnia and Herzegovina on 12 October 2014. They decided the makeup of Bosnia and Herzegovina's Presidency as well as national, entity, and cantonal governments. Voter turnout was 54.4%.The elections for the House of Representatives were divided into two; one for the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and one for Republika Srpska. In the presidential election, voters in the Federation re-elected Bosniak Bakir Izetbegović and elected Croat Dragan Čović, while voters in Republika Srpska elected Serb Mladen Ivanić. The Party of Democratic Action emerged as the largest party in the House of Representatives, winning 10 of the 42 seats. While the Bosniak member Bakir Izetbegović was the only member of the tripartite Presidency to be re-elected, Serb member Mladen Ivanić was chosen as the
paraphrase: On October 12, 2014, Bosnia and Herzegovina held general elections to determine the composition of the Presidency, as well as national, entity, and cantonal governments. The voter turnout was 54.4%. The House of Representatives elections were split into two, one for the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and one for Republika Srpska. In the presidential election, Bosniak Bakir Izetbegović was re-elected by voters in the Federation, while Croat Dragan Čović was elected. In Republika Srpska, Serb Mladen Ivanić was elected. The Party of Democratic Action won the most seats in the House of Representatives, with 10 out of 42. Bakir Izetbegović was the only member of the tripartite Presidency to be re-elected, while Mladen Ivanić was chosen as the Serb member.

title: Schellenberg smuggling incident
input: The Schellenberg smuggling incident is a case in which Canadian citizen Robert Lloyd Schellenberg was arrested, tried, and convicted on charges of smuggling drugs in the People's Republic of China. According to the prosecutors for the state, Schellenberg attempted to smuggle methamphetamine with a net weight of just over 222 kg (489 lb) from Dalian to Australia in November 2014, and after discovering that his translator had informed the police, he boarded a plane at Dalian Zhoushuizi International Airport with the intention of fleeing to Thailand. Schellenberg was arrested by Chinese police when the plane had a stopover at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport. Schellenberg argued that he was framed by drug dealer Xu Qing and that he was an innocent tourist. On November 20, 2018, the Dalian Intermediate
paraphrase: The Schellenberg smuggling incident refers to the arrest, trial, and conviction of Canadian citizen Robert Lloyd Schellenberg for drug smuggling in China. The state prosecutors claimed that Schellenberg tried to smuggle methamphetamine weighing over 222 kg from Dalian to Australia in November 2014. When he found out that his translator had informed the police, he attempted to flee to Thailand but was apprehended by Chinese police during a stopover at Guangzhou Baiyun International Airport. Schellenberg maintained his innocence, claiming that he was framed by drug dealer Xu Qing and was merely a tourist. The Dalian Intermediate Court sentenced him to death on November 20, 2018.

title: Cuban thaw
input: The Cuban thaw (Spanish: Deshielo cubano) was the normalization of Cuba–United States relations that began in December 2014 ending a 54-year stretch of hostility between the nations. In March 2016, Barack Obama became the first U.S. president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, in 1928.On December 17, 2014, U.S. President Barack Obama and Cuban leader Raúl Castro announced the beginning of the process of normalizing relations between Cuba and the United States. The normalization agreement was secretly negotiated in preceding months, facilitated by Pope Francis and largely hosted by the Government of Canada. Meetings were held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement would see the lifting of some U.S. travel restrictions, fewer restrictions on remittances, U.S. banks' access to the Cuban financial system, and the reopening
paraphrase: of embassies in both countries. This marked the end of over five decades of tension between the two nations, and in March 2016, Obama became the first U.S. president to visit Cuba since 1928. The normalization process was initiated in December 2014, when Obama and Castro announced the beginning of negotiations to restore relations. The talks were facilitated by Pope Francis and hosted by the Canadian government, with meetings held in both Canada and Vatican City. The agreement included the lifting of some travel restrictions, fewer limitations on remittances, access for U.S. banks to the Cuban financial system, and the reopening of embassies in both countries.

title: Brit Awards 2023
input: Brit Awards 2023, the 43rd edition of the ceremony, presented by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI), was held on 11 February 2023 to recognise the best in British and international music. The ceremony took place at The O2 Arena in London, and was hosted by British comedian Mo Gilligan, who returns after hosting the 2022 edition. Coverage of the red carpet was broadcast on ITV2 and presented by Clara Amfo, Maya Jama and Roman Kemp. The 2023 Brit Award trophy was designed by Nigerian-born London-based artist Oluola Slawn.Going into the ceremony, Harry Styles and Wet Leg were the most-nominated artists, with four each. Styles emerged as the night's big winner, winning in all four of the categories he was nominated in, with Wet Leg and Beyoncé also winning
paraphrase: The 43rd Brit Awards ceremony, organized by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI), was held on 11 February 2023 at The O2 Arena in London to acknowledge outstanding British and international music. The event was hosted by Mo Gilligan, a British comedian who had previously hosted the 2022 edition. ITV2 broadcasted the red carpet coverage, which was presented by Clara Amfo, Maya Jama, and Roman Kemp. The 2023 Brit Award trophy was created by Oluola Slawn, a Nigerian-born artist based in London. Harry Styles and Wet Leg were the most nominated artists, with four nominations each. Harry Styles won all four categories he was nominated in, making him the night's biggest winner, while Wet Leg and Beyoncé also received awards.

title: Central African Republic conflict (2013–2014)
input: An internal conflict in the Central African Republic (CAR) started essentially on 13 April 2013, when the government of President Michel Djotodia officially took over. The fighting was between the government of the Central African Republic's former Séléka coalition of rebel groups, who are mainly from the Muslim minority, and the mainly Christian anti-balaka coalition. The conflict was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War (2012–present). International organisations, such as the United Nations, had warned of a possible genocide. UNSC resolution 2122 authorised the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA) to be deployed to the country, and France to lead operations with additional troops sent to bolster its force in the country. Following a summit of Economic Community of Central African States
paraphrase: The Central African Republic (CAR) experienced an internal conflict that began on April 13, 2013, when President Michel Djotodia's government took control. The conflict involved the former Séléka coalition of rebel groups, who are mostly Muslim, and the anti-balaka coalition, who are mostly Christian. This conflict was part of the ongoing Central African Republic Civil War that began in 2012. International organizations, including the United Nations, had warned of a potential genocide. To address the situation, the United Nations Security Council passed resolution 2122, which authorized the deployment of the African-led International Support Mission to the Central African Republic (MISCA) and additional French troops. The Economic Community of Central African States held a summit in response to the conflict.

title: Spy Booth
input: Spy Booth was an artwork by Banksy in Cheltenham, England. The piece has been seen as a critique of the global surveillance disclosures of 2013.In 2014, Robin Barton and Bankrobber London helped with the preservation of the artwork, and attempted to broker the removal and sale of the piece. However the artwork was painted onto a Grade II listed building (153–159 Fairview Road) and the council prevented it from being removed, giving it retrospective listed building consent in 2015 and affording it some protection from removal. Despite this, the artwork was removed, destroying it in August 2016. Spy Booth was auctioned as nine stucco-faced brick fragments sawed from the wall and as an NFT.The GCHQ has used the picture, as a symbolic image for "How does an analyst
paraphrase: Banksy's Spy Booth, located in Cheltenham, England, has been interpreted as a commentary on the global surveillance revelations of 2013. In 2014, Bankrobber London and Robin Barton attempted to sell the artwork, but it was painted on a Grade II listed building and the council prevented its removal. Despite this protection, the artwork was destroyed in August 2016. The fragments of the artwork were auctioned off as stucco-faced brick pieces and as an NFT. The GCHQ has used the image as a symbolic representation of an analyst's work.
