title: Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal
input: The Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal consists of the organised child sexual abuse that occurred in the town of Rotherham, South Yorkshire, Northern England from the late 1980s until the 2010s and the failure of local authorities to act on reports of the abuse throughout most of that period. Researcher Angie Heal, who was hired by local officials and warned them about child exploitation occurring between 2002 and 2007, has since described it as the "biggest child protection scandal in UK history". Evidence of the abuse was first noted in the early 1990s, when care home managers investigated reports that children in their care were being picked up by taxi drivers. From at least 2001, multiple reports passed names of alleged perpetrators, several from one family, to the
paraphrase: authorities, but action was not taken until years later. The Rotherham child sexual exploitation scandal involved the organised sexual abuse of children in Rotherham, a town in Northern England, from the late 1980s until the 2010s. Local authorities failed to act on reports of the abuse for most of this period. Angie Heal, a researcher hired by local officials, warned them about child exploitation between 2002 and 2007 and has since referred to it as the largest child protection scandal in UK history. The abuse was first reported in the early 1990s when care home managers investigated reports of children being picked up by taxi drivers. Despite multiple reports of alleged perpetrators, including several from one family, being passed to authorities from at least 2001, no action was taken until years later.

title: 2023 PSA Annual Awards
input: The 2023 San Miguel Corporation (SMC) - Philippine Sportswriters Association (PSA) Annual Awards was an annual awarding ceremony honoring the individuals (athletes, teams, officials and organizations) and organizations that made a significant impact to Philippine sports in 2022. The awarding ceremony was held at the March 6, 2023, at the Grand Ballroom of the Diamond Hotel in Manila. More than 100 sports personalities and entities will be bestowed in the awarding ceremony, highlighted by the crowing of Athlete of the Year to World Championships gold medalist Hidilyn Diaz.Philippine Sports Commission Chairman Richard "Dickie" Bachmann and Philippine Olympic Committee President Abraham "Bambol" Tolentino has been invited to witness the affair, while Project: Gintong Alay Director and Laoag, Ilocos Norte Mayor Michael Marcos Keon will serve as a guest speaker.The
paraphrase: The 2023 SMC-PSA Annual Awards is an event that takes place every year to recognize the contributions of individuals, teams, officials, and organizations that have made a significant impact on Philippine sports in the previous year. The ceremony was held on March 6, 2023, at the Grand Ballroom of the Diamond Hotel in Manila, and over 100 sports personalities and entities were honored. The highlight of the event was the announcement of the Athlete of the Year, which was awarded to Hidilyn Diaz, a gold medalist at the World Championships. The ceremony was attended by Philippine Sports Commission Chairman Richard "Dickie" Bachmann and Philippine Olympic Committee President Abraham "Bambol" Tolentino, while Project: Gintong Alay Director and Laoag, Ilocos Norte Mayor Michael Marcos Keon served as a guest speaker.

title: Responses to the West African Ebola virus epidemic
input: Organizations from around the world responded to the West African Ebola virus epidemic. In July 2014, the World Health Organization (WHO) convened an emergency meeting with health ministers from eleven countries and announced collaboration on a strategy to co-ordinate technical support to combat the epidemic. In August, they declared the outbreak an international public health emergency and published a roadmap to guide and coordinate the international response to the outbreak, aiming to stop ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6–9 months. In September, the United Nations Security Council declared the Ebola virus outbreak in the West Africa subregion a "threat to international peace and security" and unanimously adopted a resolution urging UN member states to provide more resources to fight the outbreak; the WHO stated that the cost for
paraphrase: various organizations worldwide joined forces to address the Ebola virus epidemic in West Africa. An emergency meeting was held by the World Health Organization in July 2014, where health ministers from eleven countries collaborated on a strategy to coordinate technical support to combat the epidemic. The outbreak was declared an international public health emergency in August, and a roadmap was published to guide and coordinate the international response to the outbreak, with the aim of stopping ongoing Ebola transmission worldwide within 6-9 months. In September, the United Nations Security Council declared the Ebola virus outbreak in the West Africa subregion a "threat to international peace and security" and unanimously adopted a resolution urging UN member states to provide more resources to fight the outbreak. The WHO estimated the cost of the response.

title: 2023 Israeli judicial reform
input: A series of changes to the judicial system and the balance of powers in Israel was proposed in January 2023. The effort has been spearheaded by Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Justice Yariv Levin and the Chair of the Knesset's Constitution, Law and Justice Committee, Simcha Rothman. It seeks to curb the judiciary's influence over lawmaking and public policy by limiting the Supreme Court's power to exercise judicial review, granting the government control over judicial appointments and limiting the authority of its legal advisors.If adopted, the reform would grant the Knesset the power to override Supreme Court rulings that deem legislation passed by the Knesset as unconstitutional, by reintroducing the legislation and approving it with a majority of Knesset members. The reform would additionally diminish the ability
paraphrase: In January 2023, a proposal was made to change the judicial system and balance of powers in Israel. The initiative was led by Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Justice Yariv Levin and Chair of the Knesset's Constitution, Law and Justice Committee, Simcha Rothman. The aim is to reduce the judiciary's influence on lawmaking and public policy by limiting the Supreme Court's power to exercise judicial review, giving the government control over judicial appointments, and restricting the authority of its legal advisors. If implemented, the reform would allow the Knesset to override Supreme Court rulings that declare legislation passed by the Knesset as unconstitutional by reintroducing the legislation and approving it with a majority of Knesset members. The reform would also reduce the ability of the judiciary to intervene in government decisions.

title: 2023 Canadian honours
input: The following are the appointments to various Canadian Honours of 2023. Usually, they are announced as part of the New Year and Canada Day celebrations and are published within the Canada Gazette during year. This follows the custom set out within the United Kingdom which publishes its appoints of various British Honours for New Year's and for monarch's official birthday. However, instead of the midyear appointments announced on Victoria Day, the official birthday of the Canadian Monarch, this custom has been transferred with the celebration of Canadian Confederation and the creation of the Order of Canada. However, as the Canada Gazette publishes appointment to various orders, decorations and medal, either Canadian or from Commonwealth and foreign states, this article will reference all Canadians so honoured during the 2023
paraphrase: The list of individuals who have been appointed to various Canadian Honours in 2023 is presented below. Typically, these appointments are announced during the New Year and Canada Day celebrations and are made public in the Canada Gazette throughout the year. This practice is similar to that of the United Kingdom, which announces appointments to British Honours during New Year's and the monarch's official birthday. However, instead of announcing mid-year appointments on Victoria Day, the Canadian custom has shifted to coincide with the celebration of Canadian Confederation and the establishment of the Order of Canada. The Canada Gazette publishes appointments to various orders, decorations, and medals, whether they are Canadian or from Commonwealth and foreign countries. This article will therefore reference all Canadians who have been honored in this way during 2023.

title: 2014 Southeast Europe floods
input: Between 13 and 18 May 2014 a low-pressure cyclone designated Tamara and Yvette affected a large area of Southeastern and Central Europe, causing floods and landslides. Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina suffered the greatest damage, as the rain was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded weather measurements. By 20 May, at least 62 people had died as a result of the flooding, and hundreds of thousands had been forced from their homes. Towns of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina account for most victims, after being inundated by several-meter high waters from nearby rivers.Floodwaters caused over 2,000 landslides across Southeast Europe, spreading damage across many towns and villages. The rains activated torrents and mudslides, and subsequently several rivers in watersheds of Sava and Morava
paraphrase: From 13 to 18 May 2014, a low-pressure cyclone named Tamara and Yvette impacted a vast region of Southeastern and Central Europe, leading to floods and landslides. The most significant damage occurred in Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, where the rainfall was the heaviest in 120 years of recorded weather data. The flooding resulted in the deaths of at least 62 people and the displacement of hundreds of thousands of individuals by 20 May. The towns of Obrenovac in Serbia and Doboj in Bosnia and Herzegovina were the hardest hit, with several-meter high waters from nearby rivers causing the majority of the fatalities. The floodwaters triggered over 2,000 landslides throughout Southeast Europe, causing damage to numerous towns and villages. The heavy rains also caused torrents and mudslides, which subsequently affected several rivers in the watersheds of Sava and Morava.

title: Reactions to the 2023 Israeli judicial reform
input: On 4 January 2023, newly-appointed Israeli Justice Minister Yariv Levin announced his intention to make a number of major changes to the judicial system and the balance of powers in Israel. On 11 January, Levin published a draft of his proposed changes, which included significant changes to the judiciary, executive and legislative processes and functions. The government's proposed reform has sparked intense controversy in Israel. Opposition leaders, senior past civil servants, economists, activists, jurists and others have harshly criticized the proposed changes, arguing they will undermine judicial independence and effectively grant the government unchecked power. The opponents to the reform include reservists in Israel's security forces, with some stating they will stop conducting reserve duty service if the proposed reform is progressed through as legislation. They also include
paraphrase: In January 2023, Yariv Levin, the newly-appointed Justice Minister of Israel, announced his plans to make significant changes to the country's judicial system and balance of powers. A draft of his proposed changes was published on 11 January, which included alterations to the judiciary, executive, and legislative processes and functions. However, the government's proposed reform has been met with strong opposition from various groups, including opposition leaders, civil servants, economists, activists, and jurists. Critics argue that the changes will undermine judicial independence and give the government unchecked power. Even reservists in Israel's security forces have joined the opposition, with some stating they will refuse to conduct reserve duty service if the proposed reform becomes law.

title: Operation Impact
input: On 3 October 2014, Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper announced that he would put forth a motion to send forces to participate in the coalition for military intervention against ISIL by deploying combat aircraft. On 7 October 2014, the House of Commons approved of sending nine aircraft to join coalition airstrikes against ISIL in Iraq along with 69 special forces advisors to train the Iraqi government's military. The Canadian Armed Forces' contribution to the coalition against ISIL was later dubbed Operation Impact. On 30 March 2015, the House of Commons voted to extend the mission to targets in Syria. No additional forces were announced.In late November 2015, new Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced the withdrawal of Canada's fighter aircraft from the fight against ISIL, but their surveillance and
paraphrase: In October 2014, Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper declared his intention to send combat aircraft to participate in the coalition for military intervention against ISIL. The House of Commons approved the deployment of nine aircraft and 69 special forces advisors to train the Iraqi government's military. This contribution was named Operation Impact. In March 2015, the House of Commons voted to expand the mission to include targets in Syria, but no additional forces were announced. In November 2015, new Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced the withdrawal of Canada's fighter aircraft from the fight against ISIL, while maintaining their surveillance and support roles.

title: War on terror
input: The war on terror, officially the Global War on Terrorism (GWOT), is a global counterterrorism military campaign initiated by the United States following the September 11 attacks and is also the most recent global conflict spanning multiple wars. The main targets of the campaign were militant Islamist and Salafi jihadist armed organisations such as Al-Qaeda, the Islamic State, and their international affiliates, which were waging military insurgencies to overthrow governments of various Muslim-majority countries. Other major targets included the Ba'athist regime in Iraq, which was toppled during an invasion in 2003, and various militant factions that fought during the ensuing Iraqi insurgency. The "war on terror" was officially declared over in May 2010 and again in May 2013. Other American military campaigns during the 2010s have also been
paraphrase: initiated to combat terrorism, but the GWOT remains the most significant global conflict in recent history. It was launched by the United States in response to the September 11 attacks and targeted militant Islamist and Salafi jihadist groups, including Al-Qaeda and the Islamic State, as well as their affiliates. The campaign aimed to quell military insurgencies in Muslim-majority countries and overthrow governments. The Ba'athist regime in Iraq was also a major target, and was toppled during the 2003 invasion. Although the "war on terror" was officially declared over in 2010 and 2013, other American military campaigns have continued to combat terrorism in the 2010s.

title: 28th Critics' Choice Awards
input: The 28th Critics' Choice Awards were presented on January 15, 2023, at the Fairmont Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles, California, honoring the finest achievements of filmmaking and television programming in 2022. The ceremony was broadcast on The CW and hosted by Chelsea Handler, taking over the reins from Taye Diggs who had hosted the show consecutively in the previous four years.Like in the previous two years, film and television nominations were announced separately. The television nominations were announced on December 6, 2022. The film nominations were announced on December 14, 2022.Everything Everywhere All at Once led the film nominations with 14—a record shared with The Shape of Water (2017), The Favourite (2018), and The Irishman (2019)—followed by The Fabelmans with 11. ABC's first-year mockumentary comedy Abbott Elementary
paraphrase: The 28th Critics' Choice Awards took place on January 15, 2023, at the Fairmont Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles, California. The event recognized the best achievements in filmmaking and television programming in 2022 and was hosted by Chelsea Handler, who took over from Taye Diggs, the previous host for four consecutive years. The nominations for film and television were announced separately, with the television nominations being revealed on December 6, 2022, and the film nominations on December 14, 2022. Everything Everywhere All at Once received the most film nominations with 14, tying the record set by The Shape of Water (2017), The Favourite (2018), and The Irishman (2019), followed by The Fabelmans with 11 nominations. Additionally, ABC's first-year mockumentary comedy Abbott Elementary was also recognized.

title: Miss Grand Ecuador 2023
input: Miss Grand Ecuador 2023 was the second edition of the Miss Grand Ecuador beauty pageant, held at TC Televisión Studios, Guayaquil. It was originally proposed to be held in January but was postponed to April 15, 2023, for unspecified reasons. Candidates from seven provinces of the country, who qualified for the national pageant via an audition performed virtually earlier in November 2022, competed for the title.The event was held by a Guayaquil-based pageant organizer headed by Tahiz and Miguel Panus, Concurso Nacional de Belleza Ecuador (CNB Ecuador). The grand final round of the pageant was hosted by an Ecuadorian television presenter, radio host, and singer, Eduardo Andrade, and was live-transmitted to the audience worldwide via its international parent contest's Youtube channel, GrandTV, and was also attended by Miss
paraphrase: The Miss Grand Ecuador beauty pageant's second edition took place at TC Televisión Studios in Guayaquil. Originally scheduled for January, it was postponed to April 15, 2023, for unspecified reasons. Candidates from seven provinces of Ecuador participated in the national pageant after qualifying through a virtual audition in November 2022. The event was organized by Concurso Nacional de Belleza Ecuador (CNB Ecuador), a pageant organizer based in Guayaquil and led by Tahiz and Miguel Panus. The grand final round was hosted by Eduardo Andrade, an Ecuadorian television presenter, radio host, and singer. The event was broadcast live worldwide on GrandTV's Youtube channel, the international parent contest, and was attended by Miss Grand.

title: 2014 Costa Rican general election
input: General elections were held in Costa Rica on Sunday, 2 February 2014 to elect a new president, two vice presidents, and 57 Legislative Assembly lawmakers. In accordance with Article 132 of the constitution, incumbent President Laura Chinchilla Miranda was ineligible to run for a second consecutive term.The ruling National Liberation Party put forward San José Mayor Johnny Araya Monge as its presidential candidate; the Libertarian Movement party nominated former legislator Otto Guevara Guth; the leftist Broad Front nominated José María Villalta Florez-Estrada; and the center-left Citizens' Action Party nominated Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera. paraphrase: On February 2, 2014, Costa Rica held general elections to select a new president, two vice presidents, and 57 Legislative Assembly lawmakers. The constitution's Article 132 prevented incumbent President Laura Chinchilla Miranda from running for a second consecutive term. The National Liberation Party nominated San José Mayor Johnny Araya Monge as their presidential candidate, while the Libertarian Movement party nominated former legislator Otto Guevara Guth, the leftist Broad Front nominated José María Villalta Florez-Estrada, and the center-left Citizens' Action Party nominated Luis Guillermo Solís Rivera. According to December 2013 opinion polls, Araya was leading with 37 percent, followed closely by Villalta at 32 percent, Guevara at 15 percent, and Solís at eight percent. This suggested the possibility of a run-off vote.

title: 2023 South Ethiopia Region referendum
input: On 6 February 2023 a referendum was held in the Wolayita, Gamo, Gofa, South Omo, Gedeo, and Konso Zones, as well as the Dirashe, Amaro, Burji, Ale, and Basketo special woredas of the Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region (SNNP) of Ethiopia, on whether the included areas should leave SNNP and form their own Region. This referendum follows two previous referendums from 2019 and 2021 in other areas of the then-SNNP, both of which resulted in votes to split off into new regions. The referendum was tentatively approved, although Wolayita Zone must rehold voting after it was found that irregularities were present. The other zones and woredas involved passed resolutions to split off in July 2023, and this was conveyed to the national House of Federation by the
paraphrase: On 6 February 2023, a referendum was conducted in various zones and special woredas of the Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region (SNNP) of Ethiopia, including Wolayita, Gamo, Gofa, South Omo, Gedeo, Konso, Dirashe, Amaro, Burji, Ale, and Basketo. The referendum aimed to determine whether these areas should secede from SNNP and establish their own region. This referendum followed two previous referendums held in 2019 and 2021 in other parts of SNNP, both of which resulted in votes to form new regions. The referendum was provisionally approved, but Wolayita Zone needs to hold another vote due to the presence of irregularities. The other zones and woredas passed resolutions to secede in July 2023, which were communicated to the national House of Federation by the concerned parties.

title: Euromaidan
input: Euromaidan (; Ukrainian: Євромайдан, romanized: Yevromaidan, lit. 'Euro Square', IPA: [jeu̯romɐjˈdɑn]), or the Maidan Uprising, was a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine, which began on 21 November 2013 with large protests in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv. The protests were sparked by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden decision not to sign the European Union–Ukraine Association Agreement, instead choosing closer ties to Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Ukraine's parliament had overwhelmingly approved of finalizing the Agreement with the EU, but Russia had put pressure on Ukraine to reject it. The scope of the protests widened, with calls for the resignation of Yanukovych and the Azarov government. Protesters opposed what they saw as widespread government corruption, abuse of power, human rights violations, and the influence of
paraphrase: Euromaidan, also known as the Maidan Uprising, was a series of protests and civil unrest that occurred in Ukraine starting on November 21, 2013. The demonstrations began in Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) in Kyiv and were triggered by President Viktor Yanukovych's sudden decision to reject the European Union-Ukraine Association Agreement in favor of closer ties with Russia and the Eurasian Economic Union. Despite Ukraine's parliament approving the Agreement, Russia pressured Ukraine to reject it. The protests expanded to include demands for Yanukovych and the Azarov government to resign due to allegations of government corruption, abuse of power, human rights violations, and Russian influence.

title: 2023 Antiguan general election
input: General elections were held in Antigua and Barbuda on 18 January 2023 to elect members of the House of Representatives. The Labour Party (ABLP) has held an absolute majority of 15 seats in the House of Representatives after the 2018 general election, with Gaston Browne remaining as prime minister. Browne initiated a constitutional referendum after the 2018 election, which was rejected by voters, and following the death of Elizabeth II in 2022, he announced his intention to organise a referendum for the transition of Antigua and Barbuda to a republican system. Besides ABLP, the United Progressive Party (UPP), Democratic National Alliance, Barbuda People's Movement (BPM), and three independent politicians filed candidacies for the 2023 general election. During the election campaign, UPP proposed to raise the minimum wage and
paraphrase: On 18 January 2023, Antigua and Barbuda held general elections to select members of the House of Representatives. The Labour Party (ABLP) had previously secured an absolute majority of 15 seats in the House of Representatives in the 2018 general election, with Gaston Browne remaining as prime minister. After the 2018 election, Browne initiated a constitutional referendum, which was rejected by voters. Following the death of Elizabeth II in 2022, he announced his intention to hold a referendum for the transition of Antigua and Barbuda to a republican system. Apart from ABLP, the United Progressive Party (UPP), Democratic National Alliance, Barbuda People's Movement (BPM), and three independent politicians also submitted their candidacies for the 2023 general election. During the election campaign, UPP proposed to increase the minimum wage.

title: Action Plan against Disinformation
input: Action Plan against Disinformation (Czech: Akční plán pro čelení dezinformacím) was a material that was prepared by the government commissioner for media and disinformation Michal Klíma and his team of experts at the government office on behalf of the Cabinet of Petr Fiala. Media learned about the material on December 27, 2022. The strategy proposes possible ways of blocking disinformation, sanctioning its publishers and prosecuting them authors and distributors, but also financial support of "correct media" with tens of millions of crowns per year. The government terminated cooperation with Michal Klíma on February 15, 2023, with immediate effect and abolished the position of government commissioner for media and disinformation, which he had held since the end of March 2022, and transferred the disinformation agenda to the government's national
paraphrase: The Czech government's Action Plan against Disinformation, also known as Akční plán pro čelení dezinformacím, was created by Michal Klíma and his team of experts at the government office on behalf of the Cabinet of Petr Fiala. The media became aware of the plan on December 27, 2022. The strategy suggests various methods for preventing disinformation, punishing its publishers and prosecuting its authors and distributors. It also includes financial support for "correct media" with tens of millions of crowns per year. However, on February 15, 2023, the government terminated its collaboration with Michal Klíma and abolished the position of government commissioner for media and disinformation, which he had held since the end of March 2022. The disinformation agenda was transferred to the government's national department.

title: ARSAT-1
input: ARSAT-1 is a geostationary communications satellite operated by AR-SAT and built by the Argentine company INVAP. ARSAT-1 was launched into orbit on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana alongside Intelsat-30 satellite using an Ariane 5 rocket. It is expected to be located at 72° West longitude geostationary slot. ARSAT-1 is the first geostationary satellite built in Latin America. Total cost of the satellite is 270 million US dollars.ARSAT-1 carries a total of 24 IEEE Ku band (NATO J-band) transponders. Twelve will be operating at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz and four at 72 MHz, for a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It will offer a wide range of telecommunications, data transmission, telephone and television services mainly across all of Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay including direct broadcast

It was launched on October 16, 2014, from French Guiana, along with Intelsat-30 satellite, using an Ariane 5 rocket. The satellite is expected to be positioned at 72° West longitude geostationary slot and is the first geostationary satellite built in Latin America. The total cost of the satellite is 270 million US dollars. ARSAT-1 has 24 IEEE Ku band (NATO J-band) transponders, with 12 operating at 36 MHz, eight at 54 MHz, and four at 72 MHz, providing a total bandwidth of 1152 MHz. It will offer a wide range of telecommunications, data transmission, telephone, and television services mainly across Argentina, Chile, Uruguay, and Paraguay, including direct broadcast.

title: Death of Eleanor de Freitas
input: Eleanor Poppy Miranda de Freitas (26 June 1990 – 4 April 2014) was an English woman who committed suicide three days before the commencement of her trial for perverting the course of justice for allegedly making a false accusation of rape. Her death prompted a debate over whether prosecuting people accused of making a false accusation of rape could deter rape victims from reporting the crime, as well as whether it was appropriate to prosecute vulnerable individuals (de Freitas had been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and depression and was judged by a psychiatrist to represent a suicide risk). The decision to prosecute de Freitas was ultimately upheld by both the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Attorney General for England and Wales, while the Metropolitan Police Service paid
paraphrase: tribute to her tragic death and acknowledged the need for sensitivity and support for all parties involved in such cases. The incident sparked discussions about the potential consequences of prosecuting individuals who make false accusations of rape, particularly in cases where the accuser may be vulnerable or at risk of harm. Despite concerns raised about the appropriateness of the decision to prosecute de Freitas, the legal authorities ultimately upheld the decision to proceed with the trial.

title: Marius (giraffe)
input: Marius (6 February 2012 – 9 February 2014) was a male giraffe living at Copenhagen Zoo. Though healthy, he was genetically unsuitable for future captive breeding, as his genes were over-represented in the captive population, so the zoo authorities decided to euthanize him. Despite several offers to adopt Marius and an online petition to save him, he was killed on 9 February 2014. His body was then dissected and necropsied in a public educational class and then fed to the zoo's lions. The event received worldwide media coverage and generated responses from several organisations and individuals, including death threats to staff at the zoo.Between when records began in the early 1900s and when the animal was killed in February 2014, five giraffes had been killed for similar "conservation
paraphrase: Marius, a male giraffe residing at Copenhagen Zoo from 6 February 2012 to 9 February 2014, was deemed genetically unsuitable for future captive breeding despite being healthy. The zoo authorities decided to euthanize him due to his over-represented genes in the captive population. Despite offers to adopt Marius and an online petition to save him, he was killed and his body was dissected and necropsied in a public educational class before being fed to the zoo's lions. This event garnered worldwide media attention and resulted in responses from various organizations and individuals, including death threats to zoo staff. Five giraffes had been killed for similar "conservation" reasons between the early 1900s and February 2014.

title: Murder of Jacqueline Montgomery
input: The murder of Jacqueline Montgomery, a 15-year-old girl from Islington, North London, United Kingdom, occurred on 1 June 1975. She was murdered by Dennis McGrory, her aunt's 28-year-old estranged partner, who was described at his trial as being "wild with rage" when he sexually assaulted, stabbed and strangled Montgomery at her family home in Offord Road. Her body was discovered by her father in the early hours of 2 June on the floor of the living room of their house. McGrory was tried on circumstantial evidence in 1976, but cleared of murder. He faced trial again in 2022 under the rule of double jeopardy after swabs taken at the time of the murder were tested for his DNA and found to be a one-in-a-billion match. Following the second
paraphrase: trial, McGrory was found guilty of the murder of Jacqueline Montgomery, a 15-year-old girl from Islington, North London, United Kingdom, which occurred on 1 June 1975. McGrory, who was the estranged partner of Montgomery's aunt, sexually assaulted, stabbed and strangled Montgomery at her family home in Offord Road. Montgomery's father discovered her body on the floor of the living room of their house in the early hours of 2 June. Despite being tried on circumstantial evidence in 1976 and cleared of murder, McGrory faced trial again in 2022 under the rule of double jeopardy after DNA swabs taken at the time of the murder were tested and found to be a one-in-a-billion match. McGrory was found guilty of the murder following the second trial.

title: Backlash (2023)
input: The 2023 Backlash is the upcoming 18th Backlash professional wrestling pay-per-view (PPV) and livestreaming event produced by WWE. It will be held for wrestlers from the promotion's Raw and SmackDown brand divisions. The event will take place on Saturday, May 6, 2023, at the Coliseo de Puerto Rico José Miguel Agrelot in San Juan, Puerto Rico. This will be the first WWE event held in Puerto Rico since New Year's Revolution in January 2005, and the second Backlash event ever held outside the continental United States since the 2004 event. After the previous two years were titled "WrestleMania Backlash", the 2023 event reverted to its original name while still maintaining its post-WrestleMania concept, with the 2023 event based around the backlash from WrestleMania 39. Puerto Rico native and
paraphrase: professional wrestling fans can look forward to the 18th Backlash pay-per-view and livestreaming event produced by WWE, which is set to take place on May 6, 2023, at the Coliseo de Puerto Rico José Miguel Agrelot in San Juan. This event will feature wrestlers from the Raw and SmackDown brand divisions and marks the first WWE event in Puerto Rico since 2005. The 2023 Backlash event will focus on the aftermath of WrestleMania 39 and will be the second Backlash event held outside of the continental United States. This event will return to its original name after being titled "WrestleMania Backlash" for the previous two years. As a Puerto Rico native, this event is particularly exciting for fans of professional wrestling.

title: Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea
input: The Report of the Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea is the landmark document resulting from the investigations on human rights in North Korea commissioned by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and concluded in 2014.The report unequivocally concluded that the North Korean government systematically violated human rights including freedom of thought, expression and religion; freedom from discrimination; freedom of movement and residence; and the right to food.The Commission further determined that North Korea had committed crimes against humanity and manifestly failed to uphold its responsibility to protect. These crimes entail "extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions and other sexual violence, persecution on political, religious, racial and gender grounds, the forcible transfer of populations, the enforced disappearance
paraphrase: The Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in the Democratic People's Republic of Korea produced a significant report after investigating human rights in North Korea, which was commissioned by the United Nations Human Rights Council in 2013 and completed in 2014. The report clearly stated that the North Korean government systematically violated human rights, including freedom of thought, expression, and religion, freedom from discrimination, freedom of movement and residence, and the right to food. Additionally, the Commission found that North Korea had committed crimes against humanity and failed to fulfill its responsibility to protect. These crimes included acts such as extermination, murder, enslavement, torture, imprisonment, rape, forced abortions, sexual violence, persecution based on political, religious, racial, and gender grounds, the forced transfer of populations, and enforced disappearances.

title: Death of Ms Dhu
input: Julieka Ivanna Dhu (commonly referred to as Ms Dhu; her first name was generally not used in media reports out of respect for Aboriginal naming customs) was a 22-year-old Aboriginal Australian woman who died in police custody in South Hedland, Western Australia, in 2014. On 2 August that year, police responded to a report that Dhu's partner had violated an apprehended violence order. Upon arriving at their address, the officers arrested both Dhu and her partner after realising there was also an outstanding arrest warrant for unpaid fines against Dhu. She was detained in police custody in South Hedland and was ordered to serve four days in custody in default of her debt. While in custody, Dhu complained of pain and was twice taken to the Hedland Health
paraphrase: Service, but was discharged both times and returned to the police station. On the third day of her detention, Dhu was found unresponsive in her cell and was pronounced dead shortly after. She had suffered from septicaemia and pneumonia, which had gone untreated. Ms Dhu's death sparked widespread outrage and calls for justice for Aboriginal people who die in custody.

title: 2014 Afghan presidential election
input: Presidential elections were held in Afghanistan on 5 April 2014, with a second round held on 14 June. Incumbent President Hamid Karzai was not eligible to run due to term limits. The registration period for presidential nominations was open from 16 September 2013 until 6 October 2013. A total of 27 candidates were confirmed to be running for office. However, on 22 October Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the candidates, leaving only 11 in the race. By April 2014 three candidates gave up the race and decided to support some of the eight remaining candidates. Opinion polls showed Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani as the front-runners and indeed the results of the first round of the election had Abdullah in the lead and Ghani behind him.
paraphrase: Afghanistan held its presidential elections on April 5, 2014, followed by a second round on June 14. The incumbent President, Hamid Karzai, was unable to run due to term limits. The registration period for presidential nominations was open from September 16, 2013, until October 6, 2013, and 27 candidates were confirmed to be running for office. However, on October 22, 2013, Afghanistan's Independent Election Commission disqualified 16 of the candidates, leaving only 11 in the race. By April 2014, three candidates withdrew from the race and decided to support some of the remaining eight candidates. According to opinion polls, Abdullah Abdullah and Ashraf Ghani were the front-runners, and the first round of the election had Abdullah in the lead, with Ghani following closely behind.

title: MS Norman Atlantic
input: MS Norman Atlantic was a roll-on/roll-off passenger (ROPAX) ferry owned by the Italian ferry company Visemar di Navigazione. The ferry was chartered by ANEK Lines from December 2014. On 28 December 2014, she caught fire in the Strait of Otranto, in the Adriatic Sea. At the time of the fire there were an estimated 475 people on board the ship including 417 passengers, 55 crew and at least three illegal immigrants. Of these, 452 people were rescued and the bodies of 11 were recovered. It is known that 16 passengers died and it was estimated that there were 28 deaths overall, the uncertainty arising from estimates of the number of illegal immigrants on board. Additionally, two crewmembers of the Albanian tug Iliria were killed during the salvage operations
paraphrase: The MS Norman Atlantic was a ferry that belonged to the Italian company Visemar di Navigazione and was used by ANEK Lines from December 2014. On December 28th of the same year, a fire broke out on the ship while it was in the Strait of Otranto in the Adriatic Sea. There were approximately 475 individuals on board, including 417 passengers, 55 crew members, and at least three undocumented immigrants. 452 people were rescued, while 11 bodies were found. The number of deaths was estimated to be 28, with 16 of them being passengers. The exact number of undocumented immigrants on board was uncertain, which contributed to the uncertainty in the death toll. Additionally, two crew members from the Albanian tug Iliria died during the salvage operations.

title: Houston Film Critics Society Awards 2022
input: The 16th Houston Film Critics Society Awards were announced on February 18, 2023, at the Midtown Arts & Theater Center Houston (MATCH) in Texas. The nominations were announced on January 10, 2023, with The Banshees of Inisherin and Everything Everywhere All at Once leading the nominations with nine each. Both films won the most awards with three each, with Everything Everywhere All at Once winning Best Picture. The nominees for the Texas Independent Film Award were announced on December 7, 2022.Hosted by local film critics and film industry notables, the event featured live, abridged performances of the five Best Original Song nominees, which went to "Naatu Naatu" from RRR, and the awarding of the Texas Independent Film Award. title: 95th Academy Awards
input: The 95th Academy Awards was a ceremony held by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS) on March 12, 2023, at the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles, which honored films released in 2022.The event was televised in the U.S. by ABC and was produced by Ricky Kirshner and Glenn Weiss. Weiss was also the director. Comedian and late-night talk show host Jimmy Kimmel hosted the show for the third time, after emceeing the 89th and 90th editions of the ceremony in 2017 and 2018, respectively.Everything Everywhere All at Once led the ceremony with eleven nominations and seven wins, including Best Picture, Best Director and Best Original Screenplay for Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, and three of the four acting awards. title: Ashya King case
input: The case of Ashya King concerns a boy named Ashya King, who had a brain tumour. His parents, Brett and Naghemeh King, took their son out of Southampton General Hospital (England) in August 2014 over a disagreement with doctors regarding his treatment.Ashya had a medulloblastoma, which was successfully removed through surgery on 24 July 2014. He received further neurosurgery on 22 August.His parents desired their son be treated with proton therapy, which they felt was less harmful than conventional radiotherapy. At that time, the National Health Service (NHS) did not provide proton therapy in the United Kingdom. However, it has funded treatment abroad since April 2008 where evidence has shown there to be benefit. In this case, the doctors did not support moving the boy so that he
paraphrase: The story of Ashya King involves a young boy with a brain tumor whose parents, Brett and Naghemeh King, removed him from Southampton General Hospital in England in August 2014 due to a disagreement with doctors over his treatment. Ashya underwent successful surgery to remove his medulloblastoma on July 24, 2014, and received additional neurosurgery on August 22. His parents wanted him to receive proton therapy, which they believed was less harmful than traditional radiotherapy, but this treatment was not available through the National Health Service (NHS) in the UK at the time. However, the NHS had been funding treatment abroad since April 2008 when there was evidence of its benefits. Despite this, the doctors did not support the family's decision to move the boy for treatment.

title: Solar eclipse of April 20, 2023
input: A hybrid solar eclipse occurred on Thursday, April 20, 2023. A solar eclipse occurs when the Moon passes between Earth and the Sun thereby totally or partly obscuring the Sun for a viewer on Earth. A hybrid solar eclipse is a rare type of solar eclipse that changes its appearance from annular to total and back as the Moon's shadow moves across the Earth's surface. Totality occurs in a narrow path across the surface of the Earth, with the partial solar eclipse visible over a surrounding region thousands of kilometers wide. This happens when the Moon passes between the Earth and the Sun, causing the Sun to be partially or completely obscured for viewers on Earth. A hybrid solar eclipse is a unique type of solar eclipse that changes from annular to total and back again as the Moon's shadow moves across the Earth's surface. The total eclipse can only be seen in a narrow path on the Earth's surface, while a partial solar eclipse can be seen in a surrounding area thousands of kilometers wide. Hybrid solar eclipses are very rare, occurring in only 3.1% of solar eclipses in the 21st century. title: Western African Ebola virus epidemic
input: The 2013–2016 epidemic of Ebola virus disease, centered in Western Africa, was the most widespread outbreak of the disease in history. It caused major loss of life and socioeconomic disruption in the region, mainly in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. The first cases were recorded in Guinea in December 2013; later, the disease spread to neighbouring Liberia and Sierra Leone, with minor outbreaks occurring in Nigeria and Mali. Secondary infections of medical workers occurred in the United States and Spain. In addition, isolated cases were recorded in Senegal, the United Kingdom and Italy. The number of cases peaked in October 2014 and then began to decline gradually, following the commitment of substantial international resources. It caused significant mortality, with a considerable case fatality rate. By the end of
paraphrase: 2016, the Ebola virus disease epidemic that occurred between 2013 and 2016 in Western Africa was the most extensive outbreak of the disease ever recorded. It resulted in significant loss of life and socioeconomic disruption in the region, particularly in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. The first cases were identified in Guinea in December 2013, and the disease subsequently spread to Liberia and Sierra Leone, with smaller outbreaks occurring in Nigeria and Mali. Medical workers in the United States and Spain also contracted the disease, and isolated cases were reported in Senegal, the United Kingdom, and Italy. The number of cases reached its highest point in October 2014 and then gradually decreased after significant international resources were committed. The epidemic caused a significant number of deaths, with a high case fatality rate. By the end of 2016, the outbreak had subsided.

title: Brazilian Anti-Corruption Act
input: The Brazilian Anti-Corruption Act (Brazilian Portuguese: Lei anticorrupção) officially "Law No. 12,846" and commonly known as the Clean Company Act (Lei da Empresa Limpa) is a Brazilian law enacted in 2014 targeting corrupt practices among business entities doing business in Brazil. It defines civil and administrative penalties, as well as the possibility of reductions in penalties for cooperation with law enforcement under a written leniency agreement signed and agreed to between the business and the government. The law is directed only at juridical persons which includes corporations and other institutions, but not individuals, who are covered by other laws. The Act has been invoked numerous times, resulting in leniency agreements returning billions of reals to the Brazilian Treasury, notably the agreement with Odebrecht S.A., which by itself was
paraphrase: The Brazilian Anti-Corruption Act, also known as the Clean Company Act, is a law implemented in 2014 to combat corrupt practices among business entities operating in Brazil. It applies to corporations and institutions, but not individuals, and outlines civil and administrative penalties. The law also allows for reduced penalties if a business cooperates with law enforcement and signs a leniency agreement with the government. The Act has been used frequently, resulting in the return of billions of reals to the Brazilian Treasury through leniency agreements, including the agreement with Odebrecht S.A.

title: Global Wars (2014)
input: Global Wars was a professional wrestling supershow co-produced by the American Ring of Honor (ROH) and Japanese New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotions. The event took place on May 10, 2014, at the Ted Reeve Arena in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and aired live on internet pay-per-view (iPPV) through Ustream. The event was originally billed as "Border Wars", a name ROH had used for events in 2012 and 2013.With the exception of one interpromotional match, wrestlers from NJPW and ROH were kept separated from each other with the bookers from each promotion handling their own half of the show. The event featured nine matches with three championships on the line; two from ROH and one from NJPW. In the undercard of the event, The Young Bucks retained the IWGP Junior
paraphrase: Global Wars was a wrestling event that was jointly produced by the American Ring of Honor (ROH) and Japanese New Japan Pro-Wrestling (NJPW) promotions. It was held on May 10, 2014, at the Ted Reeve Arena in Toronto, Ontario, Canada and was broadcasted live on internet pay-per-view (iPPV) via Ustream. The event was originally named "Border Wars", which was a title used by ROH for their previous events in 2012 and 2013. The wrestlers from NJPW and ROH were mostly kept separate, except for one interpromotional match, and each promotion's bookers handled their own half of the show. The event had nine matches, with three championship titles at stake - two from ROH and one from NJPW. The Young Bucks successfully defended the IWGP Junior title in the undercard of the event.

title: 2023 Israel–Lebanon shellings
input: On April 6, dozens of rockets were fired from Lebanon into Israel, wounding 3 Israeli civilians. The IDF has said that it has intercepted 25 rockets fired from Lebanon. Warning sirens had sounded in the town of Shlomi and in Betzet in northern Israel. According to Israel, the rockets were fired by Palestinian factions Hamas and PIJ with Hezbollah's approval.On early morning April 7, the Israeli Air Force retaliated by striking targets in Tyre, Lebanon and in the Gaza Strip.In a written statement, the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) described the situation as "extremely serious" and urged restraint. It said UNIFIL chief Aroldo Lazaro was in contact with authorities on both sides. The attacks are the largest escalation between the two countries since the 2006 Lebanon
paraphrase: On April 6, a number of rockets were launched from Lebanon into Israel, causing injuries to three Israeli civilians. The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) reported that they had intercepted 25 rockets that were fired from Lebanon. Warning sirens were activated in the towns of Shlomi and Betzet in northern Israel. Israel has claimed that the rockets were launched by Palestinian groups Hamas and PIJ, with the approval of Hezbollah. In response, the Israeli Air Force carried out strikes on targets in Tyre, Lebanon and the Gaza Strip on April 7. The United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) issued a written statement describing the situation as "extremely serious" and called for restraint. UNIFIL chief Aroldo Lazaro was said to be in contact with authorities on both sides. This marks the most significant escalation between the two countries since the 2006 Lebanon conflict.

title: 2023 Berlin climate neutrality referendum
input: Berlin 2030 klimaneutral (English: Berlin 2030 climate-neutral) was a citizens' initiative launched in Berlin in 2018. It was the subject of a city-wide referendum scheduled for 26 March 2023, commonly called the Klima-Volksentscheid (English: climate referendum). Voters will be asked whether the Climate Protection and Energy Transition Act of 2016 should be amended. The primary goal of the referendum is to legislate a goal of carbon neutrality by the year 2030, rather than the existing goal of 2045. Since the referendum proposes specific amendments to the law, its result will be legally binding. In order to pass, the proposal must be approved by a majority on the day and receive approval from a quorum of over 25% of registered voters. While there were a majority of votes in
paraphrase: Berlin in 2018, the initiative still needs to be approved by the city-wide referendum in 2023. The referendum, also known as the Klima-Volksentscheid, will ask voters whether the Climate Protection and Energy Transition Act of 2016 should be changed to include a goal of carbon neutrality by 2030 instead of 2045. The outcome of the referendum will be legally binding since it proposes specific amendments to the law. To pass, the proposal must receive approval from a majority of voters and a quorum of over 25% of registered voters. Although there was already a majority of votes in favor of the initiative in 2018, the final decision will be made in the upcoming referendum.

title: 16th Congress of the POLISARIO Front
input: The 16th Congress of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Saguia El Hamra and Río de Oro (Arabic: المؤتمر السادس عشر للجبهة الشعبية لتحرير الساقية الحمراء ووادي الذهب, Spanish: XVI Congreso del Frente Popular para la Liberación de Saguia El Hamra y Río de Oro) was held in the Dajla refugee camp in Tindouf, Algeria between 13 and 22 January 2023 to renovate the governing bodies of the POLISARIO Front and establish the movement's main lines of action and strategy for the next leadership term. The Congress was also used to elect a new General-Secretary for the POLISARIO Front, which would automatically become the President of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic. For the first time ever, the candidate for general-secretary was not agreed upon before the Congress.
paraphrase: Between January 13th and 22nd, 2023, the 16th Congress of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Saguia El Hamra and Río de Oro was held in the Dajla refugee camp in Tindouf, Algeria. The purpose of the Congress was to restructure the governing bodies of the POLISARIO Front and establish the movement's main lines of action and strategy for the upcoming leadership term. Additionally, a new General-Secretary was elected for the POLISARIO Front, who would also become the President of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic. Notably, the candidate for general-secretary was not predetermined before the Congress, marking a first for the organization.

title: Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan
input: Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan was an international human rights case regarding the rights of Artush Petrosyan and his son Karen Petrosyan – an Armenian national from Chinari village, Tavush province of Armenia, who died while in captivity in Azerbaijan in 2014. The judgment of the European Court of Human Rights on the case originated in an application (no. 32427/16) against the Republic of Azerbaijan lodged with the Court under the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms by the applicant, Artush Petrosyan, on 25 April 2016. He Submitted that his son had been publicly humiliated, tortured and killed by decapitation by Azerbaijani State agents and that "his son’s body had not been repatriated in a timely manner, that there had been no effective investigation on
paraphrase: The international human rights case of Karen Petrosyan v. Azerbaijan involved the rights of Artush Petrosyan and his son Karen Petrosyan, who was an Armenian citizen from Chinari village in Tavush province, Armenia. Karen Petrosyan died while in captivity in Azerbaijan in 2014. The European Court of Human Rights made a judgment on the case after an application (no. 32427/16) was filed against the Republic of Azerbaijan under the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms by Artush Petrosyan on April 25, 2016. Artush Petrosyan claimed that his son was publicly humiliated, tortured, and killed by Azerbaijani State agents, and that there was no timely repatriation of his son's body and no effective investigation into the matter.

title: Battle of Khartoum (2023)
input: The Battle of Khartoum is an ongoing battle for control of Khartoum, the capital of Sudan, between the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF), and the Sudanese Armed Forces. The battle began on 15 April 2023, after the RSF allegedly captured Khartoum International Airport, several military bases, and the presidential palace, starting an escalating series of clashes. It was initially reported that tensions rose in Khartoum and Merowe on 13 April 2023, when RSF forces mobilized. In response, the SAF issued a statement saying "There is a possibility of confrontation between SAF and RSF forces" introducing fears of a wider conflict. In the evening of 14 April 2023, RSF forces assaulted the Khartoum International Airport, a military base, and the presidential palace. The fighting spread from Khartoum into its
paraphrase: The ongoing conflict for control of Sudan's capital, Khartoum, is being fought between the paramilitary Rapid Support Forces (RSF) and the Sudanese Armed Forces. The battle began on April 15, 2023, when the RSF allegedly took control of Khartoum International Airport, several military bases, and the presidential palace, leading to a series of escalating clashes. Tensions had already risen on April 13, 2023, when RSF forces mobilized, prompting the SAF to issue a statement warning of a possible confrontation. On the evening of April 14, 2023, RSF forces attacked the airport, a military base, and the presidential palace, and the fighting has since spread beyond Khartoum.

title: 29th Screen Actors Guild Awards
input: The 29th Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards, honoring the best achievements in film and television performances for the year 2022, were presented on February 26, 2023 at the Fairmont Century Plaza in Century City, California. The ceremony streamed live on Netflix's YouTube channel, starting at 8:00 p.m. EST / 5:00 p.m. PST. The nominees were announced on January 11, 2023 by Ashley Park and Haley Lu Richardson via Instagram Live.In May 2022, it was confirmed that the ceremony would no longer air on TNT and TBS (the ceremony had aired on TNT since 1998 and had been also broadcast on TBS since 2006); a spokesperson insisted that finding a new home for the ceremony "is not unusual and has occurred several times over the history of the SAG
paraphrase: The 29th Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards, which recognized outstanding performances in film and television for the year 2022, took place on February 26, 2023 at the Fairmont Century Plaza in Century City, California. The event was broadcast live on Netflix's YouTube channel at 8:00 p.m. EST / 5:00 p.m. PST. The nominees were revealed on January 11, 2023 through an Instagram Live announcement by Ashley Park and Haley Lu Richardson. In May 2022, it was announced that the ceremony would no longer be aired on TNT and TBS, where it had been broadcast since 1998 and 2006, respectively. A spokesperson clarified that this was not an uncommon occurrence in the history of the SAG Awards.

title: Disappearance of William Tyrrell
input: William Tyrrell (born 26 June 2011) is an Australian boy who disappeared at the age of three from Kendall, New South Wales, on 12 September 2014. He had been playing at his foster grandmother's house with his sister, and was wearing a Spider-Man suit at the time of his disappearance. For the first seven years of the investigation, Tyrrell was believed to have been abducted. On 12 September 2016, a reward of A$1 million was offered for the recovery of Tyrrell and did not require the arrest, charging or conviction of any person or persons.On 15 November 2021, after receiving new evidence, the New South Wales Police Force renewed the search for Tyrrell in three areas surrounding Kendall, assuming that they were searching for human remains. On 17
paraphrase: June 2011, William Tyrrell was born in Australia. At the age of three, he went missing on 12 September 2014 while playing with his sister at his foster grandmother's house in Kendall, New South Wales. He was last seen wearing a Spider-Man costume. Initially, it was believed that he had been abducted, and this theory was investigated for seven years. In 2016, a reward of A$1 million was offered for information leading to his recovery, without requiring the arrest, charging, or conviction of anyone. Recently, on 15 November 2021, the New South Wales Police Force resumed the search for Tyrrell in three areas around Kendall, with the assumption that they were looking for human remains.

title: World Cultural Council 31st Award Ceremony
input: The World Cultural Council performed its 31st Award Ceremony on November 17, 2014 at the Dipoli Hall, Otakaari 1 Building, Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. Aalto University acted as the host and co-organizer of the event, which was the opening act prior to the Aalto University Academic Summit titled "The Impact of Universities on Economic Growth."The WCC presented awards to two distinguished scientists. Acclaimed enzymologist Professor Sir Philip Cohen received the Albert Einstein World Award of Science for his forty-year research into cellular communication. Professor Federico Rosei accepted the José Vasconcelos World Award of Education, granted for his excellence in the field of university teaching. Jussi Nuorteva, Director of the National Archives of Finland and member of the WCC, presented the Winners' Book to the laureates. Professor Sir Philip
paraphrase: Cohen and Professor Federico Rosei were honored at the 31st Award Ceremony of the World Cultural Council, held on November 17, 2014 at the Dipoli Hall in Aalto University, Espoo, Finland. The event was hosted and co-organized by Aalto University and served as the opening act for the Aalto University Academic Summit. Professor Sir Philip Cohen was awarded the Albert Einstein World Award of Science for his extensive research in cellular communication, while Professor Federico Rosei received the José Vasconcelos World Award of Education for his exceptional teaching in universities. The Winners' Book was presented to the laureates by Jussi Nuorteva, a member of the WCC and Director of the National Archives of Finland.

title: Northern Rockies Ecosystem Protection Act
input: The Northern Rocky Mountains ecosystem in the United States is known by ecologists, biologists, and naturalists as one of the last areas of the contiguous United States that is relatively undeveloped enough and large enough to support a functioning ecosystem. The Northern Rockies Ecosystem Protection Act is designed to protect this ecosystem and the many threatened and endangered species such as grizzly bears (threatened), bull trout (threatened), sockeye salmon (endangered only in Snake River Evolutionary Significant Unit, secure elsewhere), and Canadian lynx (threatened only in lower U.S. 48 states, secure elsewhere), while creating jobs that restore old roads and clear cuts. The Alliance for the Wild Rockies based in Helena, Montana has been campaigning for the legislation for two decades with the help of numerous Congresspersons, celebrities, and
paraphrase:
experts in the field. 

Ecologists, biologists, and naturalists recognize the Northern Rocky Mountains ecosystem in the United States as one of the few remaining areas in the contiguous United States that is sufficiently undeveloped and large enough to sustain a functional ecosystem. The Northern Rockies Ecosystem Protection Act aims to safeguard this ecosystem and its many threatened and endangered species, including grizzly bears, bull trout, sockeye salmon, and Canadian lynx. The legislation also seeks to create employment opportunities by restoring old roads and clearing cuts. The Alliance for the Wild Rockies, headquartered in Helena, Montana, has been advocating for this legislation for twenty years, with the support of several Congresspersons, celebrities, and experts in the field.

title: 2012–2014 Salvadoran gang truce
input: From March 2012 to May 2014, the Salvadoran government, the Catholic Church, and the country's two largest criminal gangs, Mara Salvatrucha (MS-13) and the 18th Street gang (Barrio 18), came to a truce, known in El Salvador simply as the Gang Truce (Spanish: Tregua entre Pandillas), to lower the country's rate of homicides and extortions in exchange for improved prison conditions and certain visitation privileges. The truce's principal negotiators were Minister of Public Security David Munguía Payés, former deputy Raúl Mijango, and Bishop Fabio Colindres, and the negotiations were overseen by President Mauricio Funes. The existence of the truce was alleged by the online newspaper El Faro in early March 2012, after 30 gang leaders were transferred from a maximum-security prison to a lower-security prison, and confirmed after
paraphrase: a period of two years, during which the Salvadoran government, the Catholic Church, and the two largest criminal gangs in the country, MS-13 and Barrio 18, reached an agreement to reduce the number of homicides and extortions. This agreement, known as the Gang Truce, was based on improved prison conditions and certain visitation privileges. The negotiations were led by Minister of Public Security David Munguía Payés, former deputy Raúl Mijango, and Bishop Fabio Colindres, and were supervised by President Mauricio Funes. The existence of the truce was first reported by El Faro, an online newspaper, in March 2012, and was later confirmed.

title: Mercedes-Benz Fashion Festival Sydney 2014
input: Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week is an annual fashion industry event held in Sydney, Australia. The event is a part of Australian Fashion Week and has taken place at Carriageworks for two consecutive years. The 2014 event was held from 6–10 April. The event focuses on providing Australian designers a platform to connect with a global audience of fashion buyers, press and consumers.The industry-only event showcased over 70 designers, including 25 designers from Sydney, four from Melbourne, four from Perth, two from Brisbane and one from Adelaide. There was also one designer from Bali and China. The 2014 designer showcase featured mostly start-up labels fresh from fashion school. Lan Yu became the first Chinese designer to showcase at Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. In 2013, Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Sydney generated an
paraphrase: annual fashion industry event called Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week takes place in Sydney, Australia as a part of Australian Fashion Week. The event has been held at Carriageworks for two consecutive years, with the 2014 event taking place from 6-10 April. The main focus of the event is to provide a platform for Australian designers to connect with a global audience of fashion buyers, press, and consumers. Over 70 designers were showcased at the industry-only event, including 25 from Sydney, four from Melbourne, four from Perth, two from Brisbane, one from Adelaide, one from Bali, and one from China. The majority of the 2014 designer showcase featured start-up labels fresh from fashion school. Lan Yu made history as the first Chinese designer to showcase at Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. In 2013, the event generated significant attention within the fashion industry.

title: 2014 Gaza War
input: The 2014 Gaza War, also known as Operation Protective Edge (Hebrew: מִבְצָע צוּק אֵיתָן, romanized: Miv'tza Tzuk Eitan, lit. 'Operation Strong Cliff'), was a military operation launched by Israel on 8 July 2014 in the Gaza Strip, a Palestinian territory that has been governed by Hamas since 2007. Following the kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers in the West Bank by Hamas-affiliated Palestinian militants, the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) initiated Operation Brother's Keeper, in which some 350 Palestinians, including nearly all of the active Hamas militants in the West Bank, were arrested. Hamas subsequently fired a greater number of rockets into Israel from the Gaza Strip, triggering a seven-week-long conflict between the two sides. It was one of the deadliest outbreaks of open conflict between Israel and
paraphrase: In 2014, Israel launched a military operation called Operation Protective Edge, also known as Miv'tza Tzuk Eitan, in the Gaza Strip, which is governed by Hamas. This was in response to the kidnapping and murder of three Israeli teenagers by Hamas-affiliated Palestinian militants, which led to the IDF's Operation Brother's Keeper. This operation resulted in the arrest of around 350 Palestinians, including most of the active Hamas militants in the West Bank. In retaliation, Hamas fired a large number of rockets into Israel from the Gaza Strip, leading to a seven-week-long conflict between the two sides. This was one of the deadliest instances of open conflict between Israel and Palestine.

title: 2014 Bahraini general election
input: General elections were held in Bahrain in November 2014 to elect the forty members of the Council of Representatives. The first round of voting took place on 22 November, with a second round on 29 November in the 34 constituencies in which no candidate received a majority.The elections were boycotted by the Shiite Islamist opposition Al-Wefaq. Of the 266 candidates, 22 were women. According to election officials, 349,713 Bahrainis, including 175,998 men and 173,175 women, were listed to vote. Although the government announced the voter turnout as 52.6%, the opposition claimed it was only 30%.Independents won 37 of the 40 seats with Sunni Islamists losing two of their five seats. The number of Shiite MPs fell to 14 as a result of the Al-Wefaq boycott. Female representation was
paraphrase: In November 2014, Bahrain held general elections to select the forty members of the Council of Representatives. The first round of voting occurred on November 22, followed by a second round on November 29 in the 34 constituencies where no candidate received a majority. The Shiite Islamist opposition Al-Wefaq boycotted the elections. Out of the 266 candidates, 22 were women. Election officials reported that 349,713 Bahrainis were eligible to vote, including 175,998 men and 173,175 women. The government claimed a voter turnout of 52.6%, while the opposition argued it was only 30%. Independents won 37 of the 40 seats, with Sunni Islamists losing two of their five seats. The Al-Wefaq boycott resulted in a decrease in Shiite MPs to 14. Female representation was not specified.
